Abstract: Evaluates performance of the Thai National Family Planning Project (NFPP) from 1968 to 1975.  Purpose of proj is to deliver Family Planning Services (FP) to families.  Eval methodology based on statistics from NFPP and other agencies, interviews with Ministry of Health Staff, and on-site observatns. NFPP has brought FP to 2.275 million reducing Thailand's birth rate from 3.3-2.54%.  All contraceptive methods are available and the number of acceptors has exceeded projectns each yr: FP training is now included in all Thai medical trng progs, in which 179 NFPP personnel have participated.  Both overseas training and improved staff transportation have improvd staff performance.  Evaluator also feels clinics maintain excellent client records. Proj's impact has been impossible to demonstrate due to poor demographic records.  Problems in adequately providing FP resulting -- -due to some medical centers lacking certain forms of contraceptn such as sterilizatn; staff not dealing with numerous rumors concerning contraceptive side effects; insufficient supplies of equipment and doctors; and lack of staff supervision. Also, FP Centers are often located where land is donated and not where they are needed. It is recommended that: 1. there should be a projected target for every contraceptive method, based on the number of clinics & staff in each province; 2. doctors & equip be assigned to medical centers; 3. nurses trained abroad in operational tech be assigned to the field & not medical centers; 4. weekly supervisory visits be conducted; 5. more IUD insertion time be provided; 6. all midwives carry condoms & the pill with them into the field; 7. all FP equipment & supplies be tested for the Thai physiology, psychology, and socio-economic conditions; 8.  FP clinics be provided with at least 2 types of oral contraceptives; 9. more adequate transportation budgets be allowed; 10. FP charges be standardized; and, 11. record keeping be improved.

Abstract: BECAUSE THE TWO SEED PROCESSING CENTERS CONSTRUCTED IN HONDURAS IN 1967 HAD NOT ACHIEVED MAXIMUM OPERATIONAL CAPACITY OR EFFICIENCY, ASSISTANCE WAS REQUESTED IN 1974. WHEN THE SEED CENTERS WERE OPENED, THE SEED PRODUCED WAS OF POOR QUALITY ATTEMPTS TO MARKET IT WERE NOT VERY SUCCESSFUL; WHEN SEED WAS PROCESSED, THE COST WAS PROHIBITIVE, THE QUALITY WAS USUALLY LOW, AND THUS DEMAND WAS LOW. IN ADDITION, IT WAS FOUND THAT 1) POOR QUALITY SEED WAS RECEIVED BY THE CENTERS, MAKING IT DIFFICULT TO PRODUCE HIGH QUALITY SEED; 2) SEED PRODUCERS COULD NOT GET PAID PROMPTLY; 3) THERE WAS POOR MARKETING AND DISTRIBUTION; AND 4) PRODUCTION AND MARKETING OF THE SEED WAS NOT EFFECTIVE. ON TOP OF THESE, A RECENT HURRICANE AND DROUGHT HAD MADE THE SITUATION EVEN WORSE. THE LOAN AGREEMENT TO AID THE SEED CENTERS CONTAINS PROVISIONS FOR A REVOLVING FUND TO PAY COMPETITIVE PRICES TO CONTRACT SEED PRODUCERS IMMEDIATELY UPON RECEIPT OF THEIR SEED. PROVISIONS WERE MADE ALSO FOR THE ESTABLISHMENT OF A VERY CLOSE WORKING RELATIONSHIP (AGREEMENT) BETWEEN THE MAG AND THE BNF (BANCO NACIONAL DE FOMENTO). SPECIFIC RECOMMENDATIONS FOR AND COMMENTS UPON THE TWO SEED CENTERS ARE DETAILED IN THIS REPORT.

Abstract: THE INDUSTRIAL STANDARDS PROJECT 910 WAS AN EXPERIMENT TO TEST BOTH PROCEDURAL AND SUBSTANTIVE ELEMENTS OF TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE. AS AN EXPERIMENT, THE PROJECT MAY NOT HAVE BEEN EXPECTED TO SOLVE A PROBLEM (OR ACHIEVE A PURPOSE) BUT RATHER TO DEMONSTRATE THAT THE TYPE OF ASSISTANCE PROBABLY COULD SOLVE THE PROBLEM IF APPLIED ON A LARGER SCALE. GENERAL CONCLUSIONS AND RECOMMENDATIONS ARE DETAILED AT THE END OF THIS EVALUATION. THIS EVALUATION OF THE INDUSTRIAL STANDARDS PROJECT IS BASED ON A SAMPLING OF ITS EXTENSIVE RAMIFICATIONS. THE SAMPLING WAS DETERMINED BY READING MOST OF THE REPORTS ISSUED DURING THE PERIOD AND SOME OF THE GENERAL FILES; INTERVIEWING SOME OF THE MANY OFFICERS IN THE NATIONAL BUREAU OF STANDARDS AND AID ASSOCIATED WITH THE PROJECT; AND VISITING ECUADOR, BOLIVIA, AND ETHIOPIA. IN EACH COUNTRY THERE WAS AN EXTENSIVE ROUND OF INTERVIEWS AND IN THE FIRST TWO VISITS TO LABORATORIES OF THE STANDARDS INSTITUTIONS. A BIBLIOGRAPHY AND LIST OF INTERVIEWEES ARE INCLUDED IN THIS REPORT.

Abstract: Summarizes a four-year joint project between A.I.D. and the University of Massachusetts.  Goals in this exploration of non- formal education were: 1) To create and field-test a range of non-formal education techniques using local institutions to im- plement and support these techniques in a field situation; 2) to develop a number of non-formal educational methodologies which can be used by existing Ecuadorian institutions; 3) to implement selected methodologies with local institutions, including the Ministry of Education, with an on-going evaluation system desig- ned to provide both current as well as terminal evidence of pro- gram impact; 4) to make these methodologies available to other interested agencies and to provide support for their efforts; 5) to devise and test training procedures of carrying out these methodologies and of using the support materials; and 6) to pro- vide techinical assistance in non-formal education to the Minis- try of Education, and to assist the Ecuadorian Government and other Ecuadorian institutions development non-formal education projects.  The actual activities carried out during this project are examined and evaluated here in a question-and-answer format.  Among the materials used in this project were games, and human "facilitators" were trained to implement them. Each year of the project, the scope and goals of both the games and facilitators were evaluated and often modified or increased as needed. Now as an office of the Ministry of Education, the Non-Formal project expects to pursue its original goals. However, the scope of its work will be more limited, as will the opportunity to explore highly experimental non-formal models; the accent will be on con- solidation and systemization of the games made to date.

Abstract: AN EVALUATION OF EXISTING USAID TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO THE LAKE VICTORIA FISHERIES PROJECT OF THE EAST AFRICAN FRESHWATER FISHERIES ORGANIZATION (EAFFRO). EAFFRO HAS DETERMINED THE EXISTENCE OF OFFSHORE DEMERSAL STOCKS (MAINLY HAPLOCHROMIS) THAT COULD BE EXPLOITED; ANNUAL YIELD HAS BEEN ESTIMATED AT 200,000 TONS, OR ABOUT TWICE THE PRESENT HARVEST OF INSHORE WATERS. THE PRESENT CONCERN IS THAT OFFSHORE MECHANIZED FISHING MAY HAVE DETRIMENTAL EFFECTS UPON THE HEAVILY EXPLOITED INSHORE STOCKS. EAFFRO'S RESEARCH ACTIVITIES APPEAR TOO AMBITIOUS FOR THE AVAILABLE STAFF, AND IT IS FELT THAT EAFFRO WILL NOT BE ABLE TO PROVIDE MANAGEMENT GUIDELINES IN TIME TO AVOID COMPETITION BETWEEN THE TRADITIONAL INSHORE AND PROPOSED TRAWL FISHERY. THE ASSESSMENT OF THE PROPOSAL TRAWL FISHERY HAS NOT BEEN EMPHASIZED SUFFICIENTLY IN THE WORK PLANS OF THE USAID BIOLOGIST. THERE HAVE BEEN INSUFFICIENT COMMUNICATION AND COOPERATION BETWEEN EAFFRO PERSONNEL AT ALL LEVELS AND FISHERIES DEPARTMENT PERSONNEL, AND THE INFORMATION BEING PRODUCED APPEARS NOT TO BE IN A FORM AND OF A TYPE THAT CAN BE USED READILY BY THE PEOPLE DIRECTLY INVOLVED IN THE DEVELOPMENT AND MANAGEMENT OF THE FISHERY.

Abstract: THE LAND SALE GUARANTY PROGRAMS IN BOTH ECUADOR AND COSTA RICA WERE BASED ON TWO MAJOR PREMISES. ONE WAS THAT THERE WERE LAND OWNERS WILLING TO SELL LAND TO SMALL FARMERS AT REASONABLE PRICES AND ON REASONABLE TERMS, PROVIDED THEY WERE GIVEN A GUARANTY OF PAYMENT. THE SECOND PREMISE WAS THAT THERE WERE NUMEROUS SMALL FARMERS WHO HAD A STRONG DESIRE TO OWN LAND. IN ECUADOR THE FIRST PREMISE WAS NOT TESTED BECAUSE A NEW GOVERNMENT INSTITUTED PROGRAMS THAT MADE UNNECESSARY THE NEED FOR AID'S LAND SALE GUARANTY PROGRAM. IN COSTA RICA THE FIRST PREMISE DID NOT HOLD BECAUSE LANDOWNERS REQUIRED LARGE DOWNPAYMENTS. THE LACK OF MONEY FOR DOWNPAYMENTS WAS PROBABLY THE SINGLE MOST SIGNIFICANT FACTOR IN THE LIMITED USE OF THE PROGRAM. ONLY FIVE CAMPESINO GROUPS OF 21 MEMBERS EACH PARTICIPATED. IN BOTH COUNTRIES THERE WERE DIFFICULTIES OVER THE AID REQUIREMENT WHICH PREVENTED GUARANTY FUNDS FROM BEING DISBURSED UNTIL THERE WAS AN ACTUAL CALL ON THE GUARANTY. INCLUDED IN THIS REPORT IS A CHECKLIST OF QUESTIONS RELATING TO POTENTIAL PROBLEMS A GROUP MAY ENCOUNTER IN ATTEMPTS TO OWN AND OPERATE A FARM COLLECTIVELY. THEY CONCERN LEGAL STATUS OF THE GROUP, ITS SOCIAL COMPOSITION, GOVERNMENT, SKILLS, PAST EXPERIENCES, ACQUISITION OF LAND, USE OF GOVERNMENT BONDS FOR PAYMENT TO LANDOWNERS, WORK ROLES, CAPITAL INVESTMENTS, CREDIT, TRAINING, AUXILIARY SERVICES AND HOUSING, AND MANAGEMENT AND ADMINISTRATION.

Abstract: IN MOST OF LATIN AMERICA THE MUNICIPALITY IS THE MAIN UNIT OF LOCAL GOVERNMENT, TYPICALLY ENCOMPASSING A TOWN AND A SURROUNDING RURAL AREA. IT IS OFTEN CALLED A DISTRICT, A CANTON, OR A MUNICIPALITY, AND IT MAY BE SUBDIVIDED INTO SMALLER UNITS. MUNICIPAL DEVELOPMENT IS OFTEN AS MUCH RURAL AS URBAN DEVELOPMENT IN THE LATIN AMERICAN CONTEXT. THE MOTIVATION BEHIND ESTABLISHING A MUNICIPAL DEVELOPMENT INSTITUTION (MDI) IN NEARLY ALL CASES HAS BEEN TO PROVIDE A SOURCE OF CONCESSIONAL CREDITS FOR PUBLIC WORKS AND OTHER CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS TO LOCAL GOVERNMENTS. IN ADDITION, MOST OF THE INSTITUTIONS HAVE INCLUDED A COMPONENT TO DELIVER TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND TRAINING TO MUNICIPAL LEADERS AND OFFICIALS. THE VALUE AND POTENTIAL OF FOUR OPERATING MUNICIPAL DEVELOPMENT INSTITUTIONS ARE ASSESSED AS INSTRUMENTS FOR THE PROMOTION OF SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT. THERE IS A BRIEF DISCUSSION OF THE MUNICIPAL DEVELOPMENT INSTITUTIONS AND THE OBJECTIVES OF THE PROGRAMS WHICH THEY HAVE CARRIED OUT ALONG WITH AN EVALUATION OF THE IMPACT OF THESE PROGRAMS AT THE MUNICIPAL LEVEL. THIS IS THE LEVEL AT WHICH THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THESE INSTITUTIONS CAN BE BEST ASSESSED. THE MDIS ARE EXAMINED AS AGENTS OR INSTRUMENTS OF NATIONAL AS WELL AS MUNICIPAL DEVELOPMENT AGAINST THE BACKGROUND OF ACCOMPLISHMENTS AND NEEDS IDENTIFIED AT THE LOCAL LEVEL. THERE IS A DISCUSSION OF GAPS IN PAST PERFORMANCE AND POTENTIAL AREAS FOR STRENGTHENING THE MUNICIPAL DEVELOPMENT EFFORT. A TENTATIVE MODEL FOR PROGRAMMING FOR MUNICIPAL DEVELOPMENT IS SUBMITTED.

Abstract: THE MATERNAL AND CHILD HEALTH (MCH) EXTENSION PROJECT WAS DESIGNED AS A REGIONAL PROJECT TO ASSIST SMALL "NON-EMPHASIS" AFRICAN COUNTRIES TO IMPROVE AND EXPAND BASIC HEALTH SERVICES FOR MOTHERS AND CHILDREN AND TO INTRODUCE CHILD SPACING AS AN ESSENTIAL PART OF THESE SERVICES. AT THE REQUEST OF THE A.I.D./AFRICA BUREAU AND THE A.I.D./OFFICE OF POPULATION, A TWO MEMBER TEAM HAS EVALUATED THE MCH EXTENSION PROJECT ACTIVITIES IN THE GAMBIA AND DAHOMEY. THE ON-SITE REVIEW WAS CONDUCTED FROM MAY 18-31, 1975. THIS REPORT IS DIVIDED INTO THE FOLLOWING SECTIONS: SUMMARY CONCLUSIONS AND RECOMMENDATIONS; HISTORICAL BACKGROUND OF THE PROJECT; PROJECT GOAL AND PURPOSES; FINDINGS IN THE GAMBIA; FINDINGS IN DAHOMEY, AND CONTRACTOR PERFORMANCE. THE PROJECT GOAL AND PURPOSES WERE FOUND TO BE APPROPRIATE IN THE LIGHT OF THE GAMBIA'S AND DAHOMEY'S STATED NATIONAL HEALTH OBJECTIVES AND PRIORITIES AND OF A.I.D.'S HEALTH STRATEGY FOR AFRICA. HEALTH EDUCATION, NUTRITION AND CHILD SPACING HAVE BEEN RECOGNIZED AS ESSENTIAL MCH SERVICES. SIMPLE LOW COST METHODS OF ADDING THESE FUNCTIONS AND IMPROVING SERVICES HAVE BEEN DEMONSTRATED IN THE PILOT AREAS. IN-SERVICE TRAINING HAS BEEN PROVIDED FOR HEALTH WORKERS IN AND OUTSIDE THE PILOT AREAS. THE POTENTIAL EXISTS IN BOTH COUNTRIES FOR THE EXTENSION OF DEMONSTRATED IMPROVEMENTS IN MCH SERVICES. IT WAS RECOMMENDED THAT A.I.D. CONTINUE TO SUPPORT MCH ACTIVITIES IN BOTH GAMBIA AND DAHOMEY AND THAT A WAY BE FOUND TO GIVE MORE AUTONOMY TO CONTINUED PROJECT DEVELOPMENT SO THAT PROJECT ACTIVITIES CAN PROCEED AT THEIR OWN PACE IN EACH COUNTRY.

Abstract: REPORT EVALUATES PROGRESS MADE BY COSTA RICA'S MUNICIPAL DEVELOPMENT AND TRAINING INSTITUTE (IFAM) IN CARRYING OUT THE RECOMMENDATIONS MADE BY CHECCHI AND COMPANY DURING THE CONTRACT PERIOD 3/74 - 2/75. IFAM HAS ADOPTED A BROAD POLICY WITH RESPECT TO ITS MUNICIPAL DEVELOPMENT ASSISTANCE WHICH LOOKS BEYOND PUBLIC WORKS AND BASIC SERVICES TO COMPREHENSIVE MUNICIPAL CHANGE, INCLUDING PLANNING, ADMINISTRATIVE, AND FINANCIAL REFORMS, USING PROJECT CREDITS AS AN INCENTIVE AND LEVER. IFAM HAS ESTABLISHED A RESEARCH UNIT TO DEVELOP AN INFORMATION BASE ON MUNICIPALITIES AND THEIR NEEDS. A PROGRAMMING COMMITTEE AND A PLANNING DEPARTMENT WERE ESTABLISHED TO DEVELOP INSTITUTIONAL AND MUNICIPAL PROGRAM PLANS. IFAM PLANNERS HAVE ADOPTED A VERSION OF THE LOGICAL FRAMEWORK MATRIX. IFAM STILL REQUIRES FURTHER IMPROVEMENT IN OTHER AREAS. ASSISTANCE MUST BE DECENTRALIZED TO THE REGIONAL OFFICES, INCLUDING MUNICIPAL PLANNING. ADMINISTRATIVE AND FINANCIAL REFORMS, PROJECT IDENTIFICATION AND PREPARATION, AND REGIONAL COORDINATION. LOCAL LEVEL PLANS SHOULD REFLECT JOINT EFFORTS OF THE MUNICIPALITY, IFAM, AND OTHER NATIONAL AGENCIES. TRAINING OF IFAM STAFF WILL BE REQUIRED TO MAKE THIS EFFECTIVE. IFAM'S TRAINING OF MUNICIPAL COUNCILMEN AND FUNCTIONARIES NEEDS TO BE BROADENED BEYOND FINANCIAL MATTERS, AND SHOULD INCLUDE PLANNING AND ADMINISTRATION. IFAM SHOULD IMPROVE ITS USE OF CONSULTANTS. IFAM TENDS TO DUPLICATE ADVISORS, PROVIDES THEM WITH VAGUE GUIDELINES AND ASSIGNMENTS, AND ACCEPTS REPORTS WITHOUT CLEARLY ADOPTING THEIR RECOMMENDATIONS.

Abstract: FIRST PHASE OF TAX OFFICE REORGANIZATION COMPLETED WITH CREATION OF 5 MAJOR FUNCTIONAL DIVISIONS: AUDIT,COLLECTION,PLANNING,LEGAL COUNSEL AND ADMINISTRATION. THE IMPLEMENTATION PHASE IS UNDERWAY; THE AUDIT DIVISION IS OPERATIONAL. LEGISLATION HAS BEEN PROPOSED TO LEGALLY SANCTION ALL REORGANIZATION MEASURES AND TO VEST IN THE DIRECTOR GENERAL (DG) OF THE TAX OFFICE OVERALL ADMINISTRATIVE RESPONSIBILITY FOR THE OPERATIONS OF THE TAX OFFICE. STATISTICAL INFORMATION ON ALL TAXES HAS IMPROVED WITH APPOINTMENT OF NEW DIRECTOR FOR THE DIVISION OF DATA PROCESSING WHO WORKS WITH THE OAS ADVISOR TO IMPROVE QUALITY & TIMELY SUBMISSION OF REVENUE DATA. A SINGLE-PAYMENT DOCUMENT HAS BEEN DESIGNED TO ALLOW DIRECT PAYMENT OF TAXES TO THE TAX OFFICE. THE EFFECT WILL BE TO IMPROVE QUALITY & REDUCE PROCESSING TIME,THUS IMPROVING MANAGEMENT'S USE OF STATISTICS AND OVERALL REVENUE COLLECTIONS. TAX COURSES WILL BE CONDUCTED FOR 350 TAX OFFICE EMPLOYEES IN THE NEW SYSTEMS. A REPORT ON THE OFFICE OF INTERNAL TAXES (FOR FUELS,ALCOHOL,TOBACCO,BEVERAGES) IS NEARING COMPLETION BY AN IRS TECHNICAL ADVISOR. REGARDING COLLECTION PHASE OF PROJECT, A COLLECTION DIVISION WAS INCLUDED IN REORGANIZATION OF THE TAX OFFICE AND POLICY GUIDELINES COVERING MAJOR DIVISION FUNCTIONS HAVE BEEN APPROVED: INSTALLMENT PAYMENTS WILL BE ALLOWED ONLY IN HARDSHIP CASES; TAX AMNESTIES HAVE BEEN ELIMINATED; AN ENFORCEMENT UNIT HAS BEEN CREATED TO FOLLOW-UP ON NON-FILERS AND DELINQUENT TAXPAYERS. A MONTHLY BULLETIN IS NOW BEING PUBLISHED FOR TAXPAYER EDUCATION ON TAX LAWS,DECREES,ADMINISTRATIVE RULINGS. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE WILL BE EXTENDED TO THE TAX OFFICE,ESPECIALLY FOR THE VALUE ADDED,LAND PRODUCTIVITY AND EXCISE TAXES.

Abstract: EVALUATES USAID FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE FROM 1/1/68-6/1/75 TO BOLIVIA'S SERVICO NATIONAL DE DESARROLLO DE LA COMUNIDAD (SNDC.) SNDC HAS ESTABLISHED 5 REGIONAL TRAINING CENTERS (AT PILLAPI, ZUDANEZ, NUCCHU, PARACAYA & MUYURINA) FOR RURAL CAMPESINO COMMUNITY LEADERS. EVAL TEAM VISITED THE NATL OFFICE & EACH OF THE REGIONAL OFFICES. OVERALL THE PROG PERFORMED IMPRESSIVELY DESPITE VERY LIMITED RESOURCES. THE NATL-LEVEL STAFF WAS VERY SMALL & OVER-WORKED. THERE APPEARED TO BE A MIMIMUM OF COORDINATION BETWEEN THE TRNG DIV AND OTHER DEPTS OF SNDC -- PARTICULARLY ITS DEPT OF COMMUNITY PROJS. THE NATL STAFF DISREGARDED OTHER RELATED EDUC PROGS WITH WHICH IT COULD LINK-UP TO THE ADVANTAGE OF BOTH. COMMUNICATION PROBLEMS WITH THE REGIONAL CENTERS RESULTED FROM THE AUTOCRATIC BACKGROUND OF ITS STAFF & THEIR INABILITY TO SEE THE NECESSITY OF EXPLAINING WHY IT DID OR DID NOT DO CERTAIN THINGS. THE FACILITIES OF THE REGIONAL CENTERS WERE IN GENERAL INAPPROPRIATE AS TRNG CENTERS. THE PHYSICAL CONDITIONS WERE DEPRESSING AND IN A GENERAL STATE OF DISREPAIR. THE STAFFS WORKED UNDER TREMENDOUS CONSTRAINTS WITH LOW SALARIES,MINIMAL EQUIPMENT & ISOLATION. MORALE WAS LOW AND THE STAFF TURN-OVER RATE WAS HIGH. THE EDUC BACKGROUND OF THE INSTRUCTORS PREDOMINANTLY CONSISTED OF A FEW YRS OF COLLEGE-LEVEL AGRICULTURE. THE CURRICULAE HAD REMAINED RELATIVELY UNCHANGED FOR MANY YRS. REPORT RECOMMENDS INCREASED STAFF WITH WIDER EDUCATIONAL BACKGROUNDS FOR BOTH THE NATL OFFICE & THE REGIONAL CENTERS. USAID SHOULD ASSIGN A FULL-TIME ADVISOR WITH EXPERTISE IN NON-FORMAL EDUC,TEACHING MATERIALS & TRNG METHODS. EVALUATORS DETERMINED THAT SNDC SHOULD UPGRADE THE SALARIES FOR REGIONAL TRNG STAFFS. COURSE COSTS FOR PARTICIPANTS SHOULD BE INCREASED. RECOMMENDS THAT CURRICULAE INCLUDE MORE COOPERATIVE TRNG INCLUDING BUDGETING,BOOKEEPING AND MANAGEMENT. ALSO RECOMMENDS MORE EMPHASIS UPON HANDICRAFTS & TRNG FOR SEMI-SKILLED WORKERS--SMALL MOTORS,MECHANICS & CARPENTRY.

Abstract: EVALUATES USAID ASSISTANCE TO BOLIVIA FROM 1/1/68-6/1/75 TO ASSIST THE NATL COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT SERVICE (SNDC) IN IMPLEMENTING A WIDE VARIETY OF SELF-HELP DEVELOPMENT PROJS IN RURAL COMMUNITIES THROUGHOUT THE NATION. SCHOOLS,CLINICS,ROADS,BRIDGES,POTABLE WATER SYSTS,SHEEP DIPS,LIVESTOCK SHELTERS, SILOS & IRRIGATION PROJS HAVE BEEN THE MAIN AREAS OF CONCER. LOCAL-LEVEL WORKERS TRAINED IN HOME ECONOMICS PROVIDED INSTRUCTION IN HOMEMAKING ARTS,ARTISAN CRAFTS,HYGIENE & SANITATION AND CHILD CARE. IN ADDITION,SNDC PROVIDED VETERINARY & ARICULTURAL EDUC SERVICES TO SMALL FARMERS. IN CONJUNCTION WITH THESE PROJ ACTIVITIES, SNDC INSTITUTED TRNG PROGS FOR RURAL COMMUNITY LEADERS (MEN & WOMEN). 5 REGIONAL TRNG CENTERS WERE ESTABLISHED (AT PILLAPI,ZUDANEZ,NUSCHI,PARACAYA & MUYURINA) PROVIDING TRNG IN THE ABOVE PROJ AREAS IN ADDITION TO COMMUNITY DEVLPMNT,GROUP DYNAMICS & LEADERSHIP TRNG. GENERAL COMMUNITY-LEVEL COURSES WERE ALSO PROVIDED FOR RESIDENTS OF PARTICIPATING COMMUNITIES. DURING THE PERIOD 1971-74 THE 5 TRNG CENTERS PLUS A TRNG CENTER AT TRINIDAD (WHICH CLOSED IN 1975) PROVIDED 136 DIFFERENT COURSES BOTH AT THE COMMUNITY LEVEL AND THE CENTER LEVEL FOR A TOTAL OF 6,833 PARTICIPANTS. Abstract: Evaluates 211D grants to Cornell University, the University of Minnesota (UM), Michigan State University (MSU), and Iowa State University (ISU).  Special evaluation covers the period 5/70-3/75. The impact of 211D support on research, staff development, graduate training, and talent sharing is difficult to quantify. Moreover, grant agreements lacked specific targets for number of staff devoted to LDC-related research, foreign graduate students in agricultural economics, or use of university services by A.I.D. and LDC's.  While all 4 schools now have more faculty involved in agriculture and rural development, their use of 211D funds has varied.  Some have stressed participation of faculty from nonagricultural fields and others use of graduate students. The flexibility of the 211D mechanism has allowed support of research not germane to A.I.D.'s primary interests. Ironically, while increasing the schools' capacities to perform significant research and to develop informational and personnel resources, the grants have also in most cases increased administrative and academic demands on faculty, thus limiting time spent on research and availability to A.I.D. Specifically:  (1) The grant to ISU has increased the size of core staff for development economics.  Funds were used primarily to support graduate research.  The 211D supplement to a sector analysis in Thailand was an important use of ISU's 211D-trained faculty and graduate students. (2) Cornell also used 211D mostly to support graduate training. Faculty of the Department of Agricultural Economics have had only limited involvement, and that department, while strengthened, has not reached the point where it can provide A.I.D. with contractual assistance. (3) MSU has expanded its work in sector analysis, marketing, and rural employment generation in Africa, and in international trade and multiple cropping.  A significant new sector analysis methodology has been developed.  Most funds have been used for graduate research. (4) UM has used 211D to partially fund research and training for at least 20 staff from the Departments of Economics and Agriculture and Applied Economics.

Abstract: This project is a complex of indigenous institutions (rural banks, extension system, grain marketing agency); national media; tested high yielding rice varieties and technology for their use; and an active agrarian reform program; all being interacted upon by a farm population ready to move from a traditional acceptance of risk aversion to becoming economic partners in their country's development.  The evaluators believe that while some aspects of this program could serve as a guide to other countries, it is not replicable in its Philippine format and they caution against over-publicizing Philippine results as a possible cure-all for other countries' rural development and food production dilemmas. The project is achieving its goals.  The initial programs accomplished the two purposes set for them: alleviate the situation caused by flood and drought; and, increase production of rough rice. The delivery system set up is working quite well.  Many of the program's early problems have been overcome or diminished.  The evaluators made 14 recommendations including: (1) the Government of the Philippines and USAID should continue to support the program with particular emphasis on high repayment rates for loans and continued development of the agricultural technologists capabilities; and (2) research studies of the credit system and its uses should be initiated.

Abstract: THE PERFORMANCE OF THE AFGHAN FERTILIZER COMPANY (AFC), ALTHOUGH NOT PERFECT, REPRESENTED A GREAT IMPROVEMENT IN FERTILIZER DISTRIBUTION OVER THE SYSTEM USED EARLIER. AFC'S PROJECTIONS AND THEIR IMPLICATIONS WERE DISCUSSED AND IT WAS DECIDED THAT AFC WOULD DEVELOP ANNUAL PROJECTIONS WHICH COULD THEN BE ADJUSTED ON THE BASIS OF EXPERIENCE. AFC ALSO REPORTED THE PROPOSED FORMATION OF A NATIONAL SEED COMPANY FOR THE PURCHASE, MULTIPLICATION, AND CERTIFICATION OF IMPROVED SEED VARIETIES. AID WAS READY TO CONTINUE ITS SUPPORT TO AFC BUT CAUTIONED AFC AGAINST ESTABLISHING UNREALIZABLE OUTPUT GOALS BECAUSE THESE WOULD CAUSE DIFFICULTIES IN ANNUAL OPERATIONAL AND INVESTMENT PLANNING. Abstract: THE PROVINCIAL DEVELOPMENT ASSISTANCE PROJECT (PDAP) IS SOUNDLY CONCEIVED AND GOOD PROGRESS HAS BEEN MADE IN ITS IMPLEMENTATION. IT IS WELL UNDERSTOOD AND SUPPORTED BY MISSION AND HOST COUNTRY LEADERSHIP. IT HAS A CLEAR FOCUS ON CREATING THE SEVERAL PROVINCIAL GOVERNMENT CAPABILITIES NEEDED TO MEET THE ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT NEEDS OF PRIMARILY RURAL POPULATIONS. THE UNIQUE ADVISORY TEAM HAS BEEN AN IMPORTANT FACTOR IN PDAP'S SUCCESS. IN ADDITION, USING US EXCESS EQUIPMENT HAS GIVEN THIS PROJECT A HIGH RETURN ON AID'S INVESTMENT. PDAP'S CONCENTRATION ON DEVELOPING PROVINCIAL CAPABILITY IN INFRASTRUCTURE, TAX ADMINISTRATION, AND PLANNING AND MANAGEMENT HAS PROVED TO BE AN EFFECTIVE MEANS OF ENABLING PROVINCES TO IMPROVE SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC CONDITIONS. A PROGRAM WITH A WIDER AREA OF OPERATIONS WOULD HAVE PRODUCED LESS SATISFACTORY RESULTS. THE EVALUATORS MADE 17 SPECIFIC RECOMMENDATIONS INCLUDING: (1)EXPAND THE PROJECT TO PROVIDE SPECIALIZED ASSISTANCE TO CHARTERED CITIES IN PDAP PROVINCES, AND LATER, COUNTRYWIDE; (2)ARRANGE FOR SOCIO-ECONOMIC RESEARCH AND EVALUATION SERVICES; (3)ENCOURAGE PROVINCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE PROGRAMMING TO EXPAND ITS ACTIVITIES INTO THE DEVELOPMENT OF SMALL-SCALE IRRIGATION FACILITIES; AND (4)ENCOURAGE PDAP TO TRY TO FOSTER THE COOPERATION OF THE PRIVATE SECTOR.

Abstract: THE EVALUATION CONCENTRATES ON ANALYZING THE LOGIC AND INTERNAL CONSISTENCY OF THE PROJECT AND THE VALIDITY OF THE ASSUMPTIONS AND ON THE THEORETICAL INCIDENCE BENEFITS. ALTHOUGH PROJECT PERFORMANCE WITH RESPECT TO INPUTS AND OUTPUTS HAS BEEN REASONABLY GOOD, THE PROJECT IMPACT HAS NOT BEEN AS ANTICIPATED. THE EVALUATORS BELIEVE THIS IS BECAUSE OF UNREALISTIC ASSUMPTIONS AND CIRCUMSTANCES WHICH HAVE BEEN ESSENTIALLY BEYOND THE PROJECT'S CONTROL. THE EVALUATORS CONCLUDE THAT A BASIC PROJECT REDESIGN IS CALLED FOR AND THEY SUGGEST SIX ALTERNATIVES. THE PRIMARY RECOMMENDATION IS THAT THE GOVERNMENT AND USAID CONSIDER UNDERTAKING A COMBINATION OF THREE OF THE ALTERNATIVES. THE EMPHASIS OF THIS RECOMMENDTION IS ON IMPROVING THE EFFICIENCY OF EXECUTION OF THE LAND TRANSFER. THE NEW PROJECT DESIGN SHOULD FOCUS ON A GOAL THAT IS SPECIFIC REGARDING THE TRANSFORMATION OF TENANTS INTO AMORTIZING OWNERS AND FACILITATE THEIR ABILITY TO IMPROVE THEIR LIVELIHOOD IN THIS STATUS. THE PROJECT PURPOSE SHOULD BE CHANGED TO CONCENTRATE ON LAND TRANSFER OPERATIONS AT THE LOCAL LEVEL WITH FULLER COLLABORATION OF THE FARMER SUPPORT ORGANIZATIONS AND SYSTEMS ALREADY DEVELOPED. MEASURES OF GOAL ACHIEVEMENT AND PROJECT OUTPUT INDICATORS SHOULD RELFLECT THE PROPOSED NEW DIRECTIONS OF THE PROJECT.

Abstract: GROWING ACCEPTANCE OF NATIONAL COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT SERVICE (NCDS) AGENTS IN THE FIELD, AN INCREASING BACKLOG OF COMMUNITY REQUESTS FOR PROJECTS,AND INCREASING CASH CONTRIBUTIONS ON THE PART OF POOR COMMUNITIES ALL TESTIFY TO PROGRESS TOWARD THE NCDS OBJECTIVE OF REINFORCING THE SELF-HELP COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT CONCEPT IN RURAL AREAS. LACK OF DATA MAKES IT IMPOSSIBLE TO QUANTIFY THE EXTENT TO WHICH THIS IS SO, HOWEVER. THE PROJECTS COMPLETED UNDER LOAN 044 AND THE GROWING UNDERSTANDING AND ACCEPTANCE OF THE NCDS SELF-HELP COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT CONCEPTS HAVE CONTRIBUTED IN A POSITIVE WAY TO THEINTEGRATION OF THE CAMPESINOS INTO THE NATION'S DEVELOPMENT PROCESS. THE  NCDS FAILED TO CONSTRUCT THE NUMBER OF PROJECTS ANTICIPATED DUE TO INFLATION, A GREATER THAN ANTICIPATED SHIFT IN STRATEGY TOWARD FEWER AND MORE EXPENSIVE PROJECTS, AND OVERAMBITIOUS PLANNING. SINCE EARLY 1974, THE NCDS HAD MARKEDLY REDUCED ITS PARTICIPATION IN THE CONSTRUCTION OF RURAL SCHOOLS, WHILE SIMULTANEOUSLY INCREASING ITS INVESTMENTS IN INCOME GENERATING ENGINEERING AND AGRO-INDUSTRIAL PROJECTS.  THE EVALUATOR MADE SIX RECOMMENDATIONS INCLUDING THAT FURTHER TRAINING EFFORTS IN SELF-HELP COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT CONCEPTS SHOULD BE PURSUED WITH CAUTION AND ONLY AFTER IT IS CLEAR THAT THE ADDITIONAL BENEFITS WILL EXCEED THE ADDITIONAL COSTS BY A SUBSTANTIAL MARGIN.

Abstract: IN ALL PROBABILITY THE NATIONAL CENTER FOR AGRICULTURAL TECHNOLOGY (CENTA) WILL NOT BE ESTABLISHED AS A SEMI-AUTONOMOUS AGENCY AS ENVISIONED. CONSTRUCTION AND EQUIPPING OF FACILITIES AT SAN ANDRES HAVE FALLEN BEHIND, BUT PROGRESS IS BEING MADE AND COMPLETION IS EXPECTED BY THE END OF CY 1976. PROBLEMS OF TIME DELAYS, SELECTING AND ACQUIRING SITES, TOGETHER WITH COST INCREASES AND BUDGETARY CONSTRAINTS WILL PREVENT THE CONSTRUCTION OF EXTENSION AGENCIES AND SUPPORTING CENTERS. TRAINING OF CENTA PERSONNEL WILL FALL SHORT DUE TO SCARCITY OF QUALIFIED CANDIDATES, EXAGGERATED EXPECTATIONS FOR OTHER DONOR-FINANCED TRAINING, INCREASED TRAINING COSTS, AND DELAY IN INITIATING TRAINING. WHILE BEHIND SCHEDULE, PROCUREMENT OF VEHICLES AND EQUIPMENT IS PROCEEDING SATISFACTORILY. THE DISCREPANCIES BETWEEN THE PROGRAM AS PROJECTED IN THE CAP (CAPITAL ASSISTANCE PAPER) AND ITS ACTUAL DEVELOPMENT STEM LARGELY FROM ASSUMPTIONS WHICH HAVE PROVEN NOT TO BE WELL FOUNDED. THE PURPOSES ARE SO STATED AS TO MAKE DIFFICULT ANY OBJECTIVE MEASUREMENT OF ACCOMPLISHMENT. DESPITE THE DIVERGENCE OF THE LOAN PROJECT IN SOME RESPECTS FROM THE ORIGINAL CONCEPT, ITS PURPOSES, AS STATED IN THE CAP, REMAIN VALID, AND THEY WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED IN GREATER OR LESSER DEGREE UPON COMPLETION OF THE LOAN PROJECT AND OTHER GOVERNMENT OF EL SALVADOR PROJECTS.

Abstract: THE INSTITUTO DE FOMENTO MUNICIPAL OF GUATEMALA (INFOM) HAS GENERATED OVER 1,000 PROJECTS DISTRIBUTED AMONG MORE THAN 90 PER CENT OF ITS MUNICIPALITIES. INFOM HAS USED ITS OWN RESOURCES RECENTLY TO MAKE ABOUT THREE-QUARTERS OF ITS LOANS FOR REVENUE-PRODUCING PROJECTS. PRIOR TO 1970, A HIGHER PERCENTAGE WAS BEING USED FOR NON-INCOME-PRODUCING PROJECTS. THE FOUR MAJOR AREAS OF CONCERN ARE: (1)THE LENDING PROGRAM HAS NOT SERVED TO ENCOURAGE LOCAL INITIATIVE, PLANNING, COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT AND ACTIVE SUPPORT; (2)THE LENDING PROGRAM HAS NOT BEEN USED AS A LEVER TO CARRY OUT FINANCIAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE REFORMS; (3)THE STANDARD LIST OF BASIC SERVICE PROJECTS IS LIMITED IN ITS IMPACT ON GUATEMALA'S BASIC PROBLEMS; AND (4)MUNICIPAL DEVELOPMENT SO FAR HAS BEEN UNRELATED IN MOST INSTANCES TO OTHER DEVELOPMENT EFFORTS IN GUATEMALA. WITHOUT WELL-DEFINED ESTIMATES OF NEEDS AND TARGETS FOR MEETING THEM, INFOM LACKED A BASIC FOR SOUND BUDGETING AND FINANCIAL PLANNING WHICH RESULTED IN WIDE VARIATIONS BETWEEN PLANS AND PERFORMANCE. AID ASSISTANCE APPARENTLY SERVED TO CONFIRM INFOM'S LIMITED APPROACH. THE EVALUATORS MADE 24 RECOMMENDATIONS ON: (1)STRATEGY AND POLICY; (2)ORGANIZATION AND PROCEDURES; (3)LEGAL MATTERS; (4)FINANCIAL MATTERS; AND (5)AID SUPPORT. THEY ALSO COMPARED INFOM TO A SIMILAR INSTITUTION IN COSTA RICA.

Abstract: THE PROJECT TO DATE HAS BEEN QUITE USEFUL, BUT COULD HAVE BEEN MORE USEFUL HAD THE OBJECTIVES INCLUDED THE ESTABLISHMENT OF FISCAL INCENTIVES AND EXPORT FINANCE, AND THE ELIMINATION OF RED TAPE. SOME PROGRESS HAS BEEN MADE IN REMOVING THE OBSTACLES FACED BY EXPORTERS, AND CONSIDERABLE PROGRESS IN CREATING CONDITIONS MORE FAVORABLE TO EXPORT PROMOTION. CHIEF AMONG THESE IS THE ESTABLISHMENT OF A DYNAMIC AND HIGHLY RESPECTED EXPORT DEVELOPMENT OFFICE IN THE MINISTRY OF ECONOMY. IT IS IMPORTANT THAT AID ASSISTANCE IN SPECIFIED FUNCTIONAL AND PRODUCT AREAS CONTINUE. A FIRM COMMITMENT FROM THE GOVERNMENT OF HONDURAS (GOH) TO DYNAMICALLY INCREASE EXPORTS IS SORELY NEEDED. THE GOH NOW HAS THE CAPACITY TO HELP EXPORTERS AND TO UTILIZE ADDITIONAL TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE. NEW EFFORTS ARE UNDERWAY TO MOVE THE PROPOSED EXPORT INCENTIVES AND FINANCING LAW FORWARD. HONDURAS HAS A BASIC AGRARIAN ECONOMY WITH EXTENSIVE FOREST RESOURCES, SO AGRICULTURAL AND FORESTRY ARE THE LOGICAL SOURCES OF RAW MATERIALS FOR EXPORT PRODUCTS. AID ASSISTANCE IN 1976 SHOULD BE OFFERED IN THE AREAS OF EXPORT SYSTEMS, EXPERT FINANCING AND INCENTIVES, EXPORT MARKET RESEARCH, AND PRODUCT SELECTION IN KEY INDUSTRIES SUCH AS FOOD PRODUCTS, WOOL PRODUCTS, AND TEXTILES.

Abstract: THE EVALUATION CONSISTS OF AN OVERVIEW OF PROJECT ACCOMPLISHMENTS AND CHANGES WRITTEN BY USAID AND REPORTS BY THREE INDEPENDENT CONSULTANTS. THE CONSULTANTS DISCUSSED THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAM AND THE IMMEDIATE ACTION AND RECONSTRUCTION PLAN. THEY CONCLUDED THAT THE PROJECT SETTING WAS ESSENTIALLY UNCHANGED AND NO BASIC CHANGE IN PROJECT DESIGN WAS CALLED FOR. THE PROJECT HAD PRODUCED SIGNIFICANT INSTITUTION-BUILDING RESULTS AND HAD LAUNCHED AN INNOVATIVE PLANNING PROCESS, BOTH OF WHICH MIGHT SERVE AS MODELS FOR CONSIDERATION WORLD-WIDE. PROGRESS RESULTING DIRECTLY OR INDIRECTLY FROM THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROVIDED UNDER THE PROJECT INCLUDED: (1)THE FORMULATION OF A RECONSTRUCTION STRATEGY; (2)WORK ON RESTRUCTURING THE STRICT EMERGENCY BUILDING CODE; (3)STAFF EXPANSION IN THE VICE MINISTRY OF URBAN PLANNING FROM 20 TO 115; AND (4)INITIAL EFFORTS UNDERWAY TO IMPROVE THE MANAGEMENT AND ADMINISTRATIVE CAPACITY OF MANAGUA'S MUNICIPAL GOVERNMENT.

Title: EVALUATION OF PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION PROJECT NO. 524-11-998-106

Abstract: Evaluates the Central American tourism infrastructure loan from 2/73 to 8/75.  Loan funds are sub-lent by the Central American Bank for Economic Integration to finance public infrastructure projects in member countries (Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua, and Costa Rica). Evaluators confirm that tourism is of growing importance to the region and that the loan remains valid. Delays in completing feasibility studies have set the project back two years.  The loan paper failed to take into account potential legal problems, changes in tourism management, legislative delays, difficulties in ordering priorities, and other time consuming obstacles. While all feasibility studies were to be completed by the beginning of CY 74, the first study (Honduras) will actually not be finished until 9/75.  Evaluators recommend that the terminal date of disbursement be extended from 3/31/77 to 6/30/79 to allow for time lost in the feasibility study phase.  The projected construction phase of three years remains valid. Loan funds earmarked for promotion, technical assistance, and training are not needed and should be re-allocated for financing of infrastructure.  Promotion efforts are carried out independently of the loan by the national tourism institutes and the private sector.  Their successful efforts have increased tourist traffic by 18.4% from 1970 to 1973. Training and technical assistance are carried out by individual hotels and other tourism industries.  Both public and private sectors have successfully managed to hire and train personnel without the need of additional loan resources. Changes have been made in items to be financed.  For example, the feasibility study of El Salvador indicated that Costa Del Sur was a better site than Icacal.  Volcan Irazu in Costa Rica has been deleted because the government has already improved the road and little else can be done.  Ruins restoration has been added as a possible item for financing in Honduras.

Abstract: AID IS AT THE CROSSROADS IN ITS DEMONSTRATION OF THE POTENTIAL OF THE COOPERATIVE APPROACH TO MINIMUM SHELTER. ASSISTANCE FROM THE FOUNDATION FOR COOPERATIVE HOUSING (FCH) IS DUE TO TERMINATE, YET THE START OF THE MOST VALUABLE PORTION OF THE FIELD ADVISORS' ASSISTANCE IS OVER SIX MONTHS AWAY. IF AID WANTS TO BE PART OF WHAT MAY BE A NEW AND SUCCESSFUL APPROACH TO HOUSING LOWER INCOME HOUSEHOLDS, IT MUST CONSIDER FUNDING CONTINUED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO THE COLOMBIAN AND JAMAICAN PROJECTS. IF AID BELIEVES THAT FCH HAS DONE A COMPETENT ENOUGH JOB TO HAVE LAUNCHED THE MINIMUM SHELTER APPROACH, THEN TERMINATION OF THE CONTRACT IS IN ORDER. THE FCH FIELD ADVISORS HAVE PERFORMED REMARKABLY WELL, WHILE THE WASHINGTON-BASED EFFORTS (SCOPING THE APPROACH, IDENTIFYING THE PROJECT COUNTRIES AND PREPARING TRAINING MANUALS) HAVE NOT PRODUCED THE RESULTS USUALLY EXPECTED FROM SUCH LARGE EXPENDITURES. AID SHOULD CLARIFY THE EXACT AND SPECIFIC TASKS IT WANTS THE CONTRACTOR TO PERFORM AND STATE THESE WITH PRECISION IN ANY FUTURE PIO/T'S AND PROP'S. THE EVALUATORS MADE SEVERAL SPECIFIC RECOMMENDATIONS REGARDING (1)USE OF PRIVATE SECTOR TECHNICAL SERVICE ORGANIZATIONS (TSO'S); (2)SELECTING DEMONSTRATION COUNTRIES; (3)TRAINING AND TRAINING MATERIALS; AND (4)ASSISTING THE DEVELOPMENT OF MINIMUM SHELTER PROJECTS IN COLOMBIA AND JAMAICA.

Abstract: THE PRINCIPAL RECOMMENDATION IS THAT AID SHOULD CONCURRENTLY (1)AUTHORIZE A LOAN TO COLAC OF FROM $6 TO $8 MILLION AND (2)PROVIDE COLAC WITH GRANT ASSISTANCE DURING THE FIRST TWO YEARS OF THE LOAN DISBURSEMENT, PERMITTING AN OPERATIONS BUDGET OF $600,000. THIS WOULD GIVE COLAC TWO YEARS TO CONCENTRATE ON INSTITUTIONAL DEVELOPMENT: RECRUITMENT, STATISTICS, MOBILIZATION OF ALTERNATE SOURCE FUNDS, PRODUCTION CREDIT, AND FEDERATION RELATIONS. THERE ARE ABOUT 25 OTHER RECOMMENDATIONS, MANY OF WHICH DEAL WITH PROJECT-SPECIFIC PROCEDURAL AND PERSONNEL MATTERS. MORE GENERAL RECOMMENDATIONS INCLUDE: (1)COLAC SHOULD DEVELOP UNIFORM GUIDELINES TO BE USED THROUGHOT THE COOPERATIVE MOVEMENT; AND (2)COLAC SHOULD PERFORM PERIODIC LOAN APPRAISALS. THE EVALUATORS REVIEWED THE 1973 LOG FRAME AND SUGGESTED REVISIONS AND ADDITIONS. THEY FOUND THAT MOST OF THE INDICATORS OF SATISFACTORY PERFORMANCE HAD BEEN MET OR EXCEEDED BUT POINTED OUT THAT THE LACK OF DATA AND FAILURE TO IMPOSE REALISTIC TARGETS DIMINISHED THE VALIDITY AND USEFULNESS OF THE PERFORMANCE INDICATORS. THEY CONCLUDED THAT COLAC, IN ADDITION TO SHIFTING TO AN INTERMEDIATE CREDIT INSTITUTION, HAD PROVIDED TRAINING AND OTHER ASSISTANCE ACTIVITIES DURING 1974 WHICH SPELLED CONTINUED GROWTH TO FEDERATIONS. THE REPORT DISCUSSES SOME OF THE CHANGES IN THE MOVEMENT: MORE MODERN ORGANIZATION AND BUSINESS PRACTICES, THE RISE IN PROFESSIONALISM OF PERSONNEL, AND GREATER DEPENDENCE ON EXTERNAL CAPITAL AND FINANCING. THE REPORT ALSO CONTAINS A SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT ON CREDIT UNIONS IN SIX LATIN AMERICAN COUNTRIES BASED ON THE EVALUATORS' FIELD VISITS.

Abstract: THE OBJECTIVE OF THE HASSAN II PROJECT IS TO ASSIST HASSAN II IN PLANNING CURRICULUM, AND IN DEVELOPING ADVANCED TEACHING AND RESEARCH CAPABILITIES. THERE HAS BEEN LITTLE ACTIVITY IN CURRICULUM PLANNING. THE OBJECTIVE OF DEVELOPING ADVANCED TEACHING CAPABILITIES HAS BEEN ONLY MARGINALLY REALIZED. AS FAR AS DEVELOPING ADVANCED RESEARCH CAPABILITIES IS CONCERNED, MOST PROJECT RESOURCES HAVE BEEN CONSUMED IN PERFORMING RESEARCH PER SE. AFTER AN AVERAGE OF WELL OVER THREE YEARS ON THE JOB PER MAN, NONE OF THE FOUR TEAM MEMBERS HAS SUCCEEDED IN TRAINING A REPLACEMENT WHO MIGHT CARRY ON RESEARCH PROGRAMS BEGUN DURING THE PROJECT. POSITIVE ACCOMPLISHMENTS INCLUDE HIGH QUALITY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT OF A COMPREHENSIVE SOILS CAPABILITY MAP. THE EVALUATORS CONCLUDE THAT: (1)CONTINUATION OF THE PROJECT IN ITS PRESENT FORM, WITHOUT FURTHER ARTICULATION OF OBJECTIVES, IS NOT WARRANTED; (2)IT HAS NOT PROVEN PLAUSIBLE FOR US INVESTMENT TO SERIOULSY EFFECT HASSAN II CAPABILITY TO MEET MOROCCO'S NEED FOR HIGH EXPERTISE AGRICULTURAL MANPOWER; (3)HASSAN II INSTITUTE IS A VIABLE INSTITUTION WITHOUT ANY USAID INTERVENTION AND WOULD PERSERVERE WITHOUT US ASSISTANCE; AND (4)IF US INVESTMENT IS TO MATTER, IT WILL MATTER IN TERMS OF THE RESEARCH CAPABILITY ADDED TO MOROCCO.

Abstract: EVALUATION REPORTS FOR THE CAMEROON AND KENYA ACTIVITIES WERE PREPARED IN SEPARATE PARTS. THE EVALUATORS WERE WELL SATISFIED WITH THE PERFORMANCE OF THE PROJECT PERSONNEL. BOTH PROJECTS HAVE BEEN SERIOUSLY DELAYED FOR DIFFERING AND UNANTICIPATED REASONS. IN KENYA, THE WORK HAS BEEN HINDERED PRINCIPALLY BY THE EXTENT OF COMPUTER CONVERSION UNDERTAKEN IN THE CENTRAL BUREAU OF STATISTICS. IN CAMEROON THE DELAY WAS ATTRIBUTED PRINCIPALLY TO TIME CONSUMED IN CLEARANCES AT VARIOUS LEVELS AND THE FACT THAT THE CAMEROON PROJECT AGREEMENT WAS NOT SIGNED UNTIL FEBRUARY 1975. IT WAS THE UNANIMOUS OPINION OF THE EVALUATORS THAT THE PROJECT WILL PROVE TO BE EXTREMELY HELPFUL TO BOTH COUNTRIES IN THE USE OF DATA FOR DECISION-MAKING CONCERNING POPULATION AND OTHER SOCIO-ECONOMIC POLICIES. IT IS RECOMMENDED THAT THE NECESSARY ADDITIONAL TIME THROUGH JUNE 30, 1976, BE GRANTED AND THAT SUFFICIENT FUNDS BE PROVIDED THROUGH THE PERIOD TO PERMIT THE SATISFACTORY COMPLETION OF THE OBJECTIVES SPECIFIED AND TO ENSURE THAT LOCAL COUNTERPARTS ARE SUFFICIENTLY TRAINED AND EXPERIENCED TO CARRY ON THE PROGRAM. THE EVALUATORS MADE 24 SPECIFIC RECOMMENDATIONS.

Abstract: THIS PROJECT IS PART OF THE KENYA LIVESTOCK LOAN PROGRAM INWHICH GOK, AID, IDA, CIDA, AND UKODM PARTICIPATE. THE GOALS TO INCREASE LIVESTOCK PRODUCTION AND FOREIGN EXCHANGE, GIVEN SUFFICIENT TIME AND INPUTS, ARE WITHIN REALIZATION. THERE IS NOT REASON TO QUESTION THE BASIC PROJECT DESIGN; EMPHASIS SHOULD NOT BE ON REDESIGN BUT ON MORE EFFECTIVE COORDINATED EFFORT. Abstract: THE PROJECT WAS EVALUATED DURING THE FIRST OF TWO PLANNED PHASES. THE PROJECT GOAL IS TO IMPROVE LIVESTOCK PRODUCTION EFFICIENCY BY INTRODUCING PACKAGES OF PRODUCTION PRACTICES TO TRADITIONAL LIVESTOCK PRODUCERS THROUGH PRODUCER ASSOCIATIONS. FINDINGS ARE: (1)ON BALANCE, PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION HAS PROCEEDED AT AN ACCEPTABLE RATE; (2)THE JOINT MULTIDONOR ARRANGEMENTS BETWEEN AID, UNDP, AND FAC HAVE WORKED WELL; (3)INFRASTRUCTURE AND INSTITUTION BUILDING ARE WELL UNDERWAY; (4)GOOD PROGRESS HAS BEEN MADE IN ANIMAL HEALTH AND WATER DEVELOPMENT; AND (5)INCREASED LIVESTOCK NUMBERS HIGHLIGHT THE DANGER OF FURTHER RESOURCE DEGRADATION FROM OVERSTOCKING AND THE NEED FOR MORE RAPID INVOLVEMENT OF PRODUCERS. RECOMMENDATIONS FOR THE REMAINDER OF PHASE I ARE: (1)SHIFT EMPHASIS TO THOSE PROJECT COMPONENTS WHICH INCREASE OFFTAKE AND RETARD RESOURCE DEGRADATION; (2)GIVE HIGH PRIORITY TO MARKETING AS A MEANS OF OPTIMIZING HERD OFFTAKE; (3)EXPEDITE ORGANIZATION AND TRAINING OF APPROPRIATE PERSONNEL IN PRODUCER ASSOCIATIONS; (4)CONCENTRATE EXTENSION ACTIVITIES ONLY ON THE MOST PROMISING ACTIVITIES; (5)RESTRUCTURE PARTICIPANT TRAINING IN SUPPORT OF PROJECT REQUIREMENTS; AND (6)MAKE A PRODUCTION MODEL OF PROJECT CATTLE. THE MAJOR CONSIDERATION FOR PHASE II PROJECT DESIGN IS THE NEED FOR A NEW STRATEGY AIMED AT INCREASING THE EFFICIENCY OF DIVERSIFIED OR MIXED LIVESTOCK AND AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION.

Abstract: THE WORK ORIENTED ADULT EDUCATION PROGRAM IS A THREE-YEAR PROJECT TO DESIGN, DEVELOP, TEST, AND EVALUATE AN ORGANIZATION AND SYSTEM FOR DELIVERING RELEVANT LEARNING TO RURAL ADULTS AND OUT-OF-SCHOOL YOUTH. THE CAREFUL PLANNING PROCESS USED IS CONSIDERED A VERY GOOD FORMAT,BUT MORE ATTENTION SHOULD HAVE BEEN GIVEN TO CONTINUITY OF PARTICIPANTS, OPEN ACCESS TO BACKGROUND DOCUMENTS, AND A CLEARER DEFINITION OF RESPONSIBILITIES OF ALL PARTIES INVOLVED IN THE PLANNING PROCESS. THE PROJECT PLAN NEEDS SOME REVISION, BUT THE FAILURE TO ACCOMPLISH MORE DURING THE IMPLEMENTATION PHASE IS NOT ATTRIBUTED TO DESIGN PROBLEMS. DURING THE SIX MONTHS' IMPLEMENTATION, SERIOUS MANAGEMENT, LEADERSHIP, AND ADMINISTRATIVE PROBLEMS WERE ALREADY INHIBITING THE PROJECT. RECOMMENDATIONS FOR RELEVANT, WORK-ORIENTED TRAINING FOR THE RURAL MASSES SHOULD BE CONTINUED; (2)THE PROJECT SHOULD BE REDESIGNED; (3)THE APPROACH OF THE PROJECT SHOULD BE CHANGED FROM ITS EXPERIMENTAL MOLD TO ONE OF DELIVERY SYSTEM DESIGN, DEVELOPMENT, AND EVALUATION; AND (4)FUNDAMENTAL DECISIONS SHOULD BE REVIEWED TO PROVIDE THE REDESIGNERS WITH CLEAR GUIDELINES ON SUCH TOPICS AS URBAN VS RURAL, YOUTH VS ADULTS, AGRARIAN VS CRAFTS-TRAINING, AND INDIVIDUAL VS COMMUNAL PROGRAMS.

Abstract: THE LIBERIAN INSTITUTE OF PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION (LIPA) CONTRIBUTES TO THE GOVERNMENT OF LIBERIA'S (GOL) GOAL OF IMPROVED GOVERNMENT ADMINISTRATION BY DEVELOPING MANAGERIAL SKILLS OF GOVERNMENT EMPLOYEES AND BY PROVIDING SPECIFIC CONSULTING SERVICES. THE FIRST COMPREHENSIVE SURVEY OF LIBERIAN PUBLIC SERVICE MANAGEMENT TRAINING NEEDS AND SEVERAL TRAINING PROGRAMS HAVE BEEN COMPLETED. LIPA IS AT THE POINT OF TAKE-OFF FOR MORE SIGNIFICANT GROWTH AND DEVELOPMENT PROVIDED IT RECEIVES NECESSARY FINANCIAL, LOGISTIC, AND OTHER SUPPORT FROM THE GOL. Abstract: THABA BOSIU HAS MADE A SIGNIFICANT CONTRIBUTION TO AGRICULTURAL DEVELOPMENT IN LESOTHO IN EVOLVING A PROCESS BY WHICH THE GOVERNMENT OF LESOTHO (GOL) CAN REACH AND INFLUENCE RURAL PEOPLE TO ACCEPT CHANGE. IT HAS SURFACED A GREAT DEAL OF INFORMATION ON THE MOTIVATION OF THE BASOTHO AND THE REASONS FOR LOW AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION. WITH THE POSSIBLE EXCEPTION OF PROFITS TO SOME VILLAGES FROM FISH PONDS, IT HAS NOT YET CAUSED ANY INCREASE IN RURAL INCOME AND, WITH THE EXCEPTION OF A FEW HOUSEHOLDS, WILL NOT BRING ABOUT AN APPRECIABLE INCREASE DURING THE LIFE OF THE PROJECT. IT HAS DEMONSTRATED THAT BASOTHO PERSONNEL EMPLOYED BY THE PROJECT, AND PRESUMABLY OTHERS, CAN BE TRAINED FOR TECHNICAL TASKS. IT HAS DEMONSTRATED THAT, GIVEN THE TIME, MONEY, MACHINERY, AND SKILLED MANPOWER, CONSERVATION MEASURES CAN BE INSTALLED IN A WORKMANLIKE MANNER. THE APPROACH WHICH SHOULD COME INTO PLAY NOW IS MODIFYING TRADITIONAL FARMING SYSTEMS AND ADOPTING CROPPING AND HUSBANDRY PRACTICES WHICH ARE CONSISTENT WITH SOIL AND RANGE CONSERVATION. THE EVALUATORS RECOMMEND THAT AID, GOL, AND THE PROJECT MANAGEMENT BROADEN THE SEARCH FOR HIGH INCOME CROPS, LIVESTOCK, POULTRY, AND MANAGMENT SYSTEMS, AND MAKE 21 OTHER SPECIFIC RECOMMENDATIONS DEALING PRIMARILY WITH ADMINISTRATION AND PERSONNEL.

Title: PROJECT APPRAISAL REPORT; MATERNAL AND CHILD HEALTH/FAMILY PLANNING TRAINING; BOTSWANA PROJECT NO. (690-11-540-032)

Abstract: THE PROJECT GOAL AND PURPOSES ARE APPROPRIATE IN THE LIGHT OF THE GAMBIA'S AND DAHOMEY'S STATED NATIONAL HEALTH OBJECTIVES AND PRIORITIES AND OF AID'S HEALTH STRATEGY FOR AFRICA. THE MAJORITY OF PHASE I TARGETS ARE BEING OR HAVE BEEN MET AND, IN MANY INSTANCES, SURPASSED. HEALTH EDUCATION, NUTRITION, AND CHILD SPACING HAVE BEEN RECOGNIZED AS ESSENTIAL MCH SERVICES. SIMPLE LOW COST METHODS OF ADDING THESE FUNCTIONS AND IMPROVING SERVICES HAVE BEEN DEMONSTRATED IN THE PILOT AREAS. IN-SERVICE TRAINING HAS BEEN PROVIDED FOR HEALTH WORKERS IN AND OUTSIDE THE PILOT AREAS. CERTAIN PROJECT DESIGN ASSUMPTIONS SUCH AS DIVIDING THE PROJECT INTO TWO PHASES HAVE NOT PROVEN VALID. THE POTENTIAL FOR EXTENSION OF DEMONSTRATED IMPROVEMENTS IN MCH/CS SERVICES EXISTS IN BOTH COUNTRIES. RECOMMENDATIONS INCLUDE: (1)THAT AID CONTINUE TO SUPPORT MCH PROJECT ACTIVITIES IN BOTH GAMBIA AND DAHOMEY; (2)THAT A WAY BE FOUND TO GIVE MORE AUTONOMY TO CONTINUED PROJECT DEVELOPMENT IN EACH COUNTRY SO THAT PROJECT ACTIVITIES IN EACH COUNTRY CAN PROCEED AT THEIR OWN PACE; AND (3)THAT CONSIDERATION BE GIVEN TO EXTENDING THE LIFE OF THE PROJECT SO THAT PHASE II IS LONG ENOUGH TO GIVE MEANINGFUL SUPPORT TO AGREED-UPON EXTENSION ACTIVITIES.

Abstract: THE AFRICN PRIMARY SCIENCE PROGRAMME (APSP) HAD AS ITS MAJOR GOALS (1) RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT OF NEW IDEAS IN TEACHING SCIENCE IN AFRICAN PRIMARY SCHOOLS; (2) PRODUCTING MATERIALS DESIGNED FOR USE IN AFRICAN TEACHER TRAINING COLLEGES; (3) IMPLEMENTATION OF THE PROGRAM THROUGH MANPOWER DEVELOPMENT; AND (4) EVENTUAL PHASING OUT OF OUTSIDE INFLUENCE AND THE INSTITUTIONALIZATION OF INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION IN SCIENCE CURRICULUM DEVELOPMENT IN AFRICA. TO ASSIST AID IN ACHIEVING THESE GOALS THE SCIENCE EDUCATION PROGRAM FOR AFRICA (SEPA) WAS FORMED. SEPA IS ONE THE MOST SUCCESSFUL ENTERPRISES OF ITS KIND. SIMILAR ATTEMPTS IN OTHER SUBJECT AREAS HAVE NOT SUCCEEDED IN ACHIEVING THE LEVEL OF SUPPORT, PRESTIGE OR EFFECTINVENESS THAT PRESENTLY CHARACTERIZES SEPA. IT HAS ENCOURAGED INNOVATION AND LOCAL ADAPTATION, WHILE ENHANCING THE ROLE OF THE MINISTRIES AS WELL AS THAT OF THE CLASSROOM TEACHER. MATERIALS PRODUCTION IS ON SCHEDULE. BOTH THE SCIENCE EDUCATION HANDBOOK AN THE TEACHER TRAINING GUIDE SHOULD BE READY FOR DISTRIBUTION BEFORE FY 76. EFFORTS ARE UNDERWAY TO UNDERTAKE  RESEARCH IN TEACHER TRAINING AND MATERIALS DEVELOPMENT WITH THE AID OF INCREASING INSTRUCTIONAL EFFECTIVENESS. THE RESIDENT TRAINING PROGRAM AT NJALA HOLDS MUCH PROMISE FOR PROVIDING A CADRE OF TRAINED PERSONNEL WHICH COULD HAVE A SIGNIFICANT INFLUENCE ON LOCAL CURRICULA.

Title: AMERICAN COUNCIL ON EDUCATION OVERSEAS LIAISON COMMITTEE; END OF PROJECT REVIEW; SEPA/EDC/APSP

Abstract: DURING THE FIRST TEN YEARS OF THE OPERATION, THE PAN AFRICAN INSTITUTE FOR DEVELOPMENT (PAID) HAS ATTRACTED SUBSTANTIAL FINANCIAL SUPPORT FROM MORE THAN TWENTY BILATERAL, MULTI-LATERAL, OR PRIVATE DONOR AGENCIES. PAID HAS ALSO ADVANCED TOWARD ITS OBJECTIVE OF PAN AFRICANISM, AS ILLUSTRATED BY ITS GRADUATES FROM 32 AFRICAN NATIONS, BY ITS MULTI-NATIONAL AFRIAN STAFF, AND BY ITS EXPANDING NETWORK OF CONTACTS WITH AFRICAN LEADERS, INSTITUTIONS, AND REGIONAL ORGANIZATIONS. PAID WAS EARLY IN IDENTIFYING AND RESPONDING TO SPECIFIC MANPOWER TRAINING NEEDS IN TERMS OF AFRICAN DEVELOPMENTAL PROBLEMS. THE ORGANIZATION HAS MAINTAINED AN EXPERIMENTAL APPROACH IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF ITS SEVERAL INSTITUTIONS AND PROGRAMS. PAID IS INFRASTRUCTURAL IN NATURE, CROSSING SECTORS AND DISCIPLINES, AND ENABLING THE DEVELOPMENT PROFESSIONALS OF BOTH WORLDS TO GET ON WITH THEIR COMMON EFFORTS. ITS INTENTION IS TO GENERATE AND PERFECT KEY ADMINISTRATIVE MANPOWER THAT WILL MAKE A GREAT VARIETY OF DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS MOVE FASTER AND BETTER. THE EVALUATORS RECOMMEND THAT, BASED ON PAID'S DEMONSTRATED ACCEPTANCE, STABILITY, AND UTILITY, AID SHOULD MAINTAIN A STRONG CONTINUING INTEREST IN PAID'S ACTIVITIES, INCLUDING FINANCIAL SUPPORT, AS LONG AS AID'S PERCEPTION OF THE UNSATISFIED NEEDS REMAINS FIRM AND THE QUALITY OF PAID AS A CHOSEN INSTRUMENT REMAINS HIGH. THE EVALUATORS DISCUSSED AND MADE RECOMMENDATIONS ABOUT 14 ISSUES.

Title: REPORT AND RECOMMENDATIONS ON THE PAN AFRICAN INSTITUTE FOR DEVELOPMENT (INTERNAL USE ONLY)

Abstract: THE EVALUATION PANEL HAS DIFFICULTY IN EVALUATING THE PROJECT ACCOMPLISHMENTS AND PERFORMANCE OF THE CONTRACTOR DURING THE FIVE YEARS OF THE PROJECT DUE TO A LACK OF CLEAR DEFINITION THE OBJECTIVES AND FOCUS IN THE ORIGINAL PROJECT DESIGN. ABOUT 60 DEFINABLE ACTIVITIES WERE IMPLEMENTED UNDER THE CONTRACT. WITH ONLY ONE OR TWO EXCEPTIONS, NONE OF THE ACTIVITIES WAS LARGE ENOUGH TO BRING ABOUT OBVIOUS AND DIRECTLY ATTRIBUTABLE CHANGES IN AID OR THE LDC'S. THE PANEL AGREED THAT THE PAST PERFORMANCES OF THE NATIONAL ACADEMY OF SCIENCE (NAS) HAS BEEN GOOD, HAS LAID A FOUNDATION FOR PROVIDING ADVICE ON SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY RELATED TO DEVELOPMENT, AND SHOULD  BE CONTINUED. HOWEVER, IN DEVELOPING A NEW PROJECT, CARE SOULD BE TAKEN TO INSURE THAT OBJECTIVES AND THE METHOD FOR FURTHER EVALUATION BE CLEARLY DEFINED. THE PANEL AGREED THAT THE REPORTS, WORKSHOPS, ETC OF THE PROJECT HAVE BEEN A SIGNIFICANT SOURCE OF HIGH QUALITY INDEPENDENT AND OBJECTIVE ANALYSIS AND RECOMMENDATIONS. A POSITIVE THOUGH UNMEASURABLE PRODUCT OF THIS PROJECT IS THE DEVELOPMENT OF A SCIENTIFIC NETWORK THROUGH WHICH LDC SCIENTISTS CAN BE IN REGULAR CONTACT WITH THEIR COLLEGUES COMPLETELY OUTSIDE OF GOVERNMENT CHANNELS. THE PANEL FEELS THAT PAST PERFORMANCE HAS BEEN WEAK IN THE AREAS OF PLANNING/PREPARATION AND FOLLOW-UP/EVALUATION. THE PANEL MADE 33 RECOMMENDATIONS REGARDING CHANGES AND IMPROVEMENTS IN PROJECT DESIGN, PROJECT PERFORMANCE, AND PROJECT MANAGEMENT AND CONTRACTING.

Title: EVALUATION REPORT; STERENGTHENING THE SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL CAPABILITIES OF DEVELOPING COUNTRIES

Abstract: AFTER AN INITIAL YEAR-AND-A-HALF OF UNCERTAIN EFFORT,SUBSTANTIVE WORK BEGAN WITH THE APPOINTMENT OF A NEW MANAGER. NOW, IN THE THIRD YEAR OF THIS NEW EFFORT, THE PROJECT IS BEGINNING TO PAY OFF IN USEFUL PRODUCTS FOR DEVELOPMENT, SUPPORTS FOR INSTITUTION BUILDING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE METHODOLOGY. AFTER THE FIRST INEFFECTIVE YEAR-AND-A-HALF OF THE GRANT CALENDAR, THE TIME REMAINING FOR THE PROJECT TO MEET GOALS SET INITIALLY IN A FIVE-YEAR CONTEXT IS INADEQUATE. AID WAS LESS THAN CLEAR IN DEFINING THE PURPOSES OF THE PROGRAM EITHER IN THE GRANT DOCUMENT OR IN THE COURSE OF ITS EXECUTION. THE WIDE-RANGING SCOPE OF ACTIVITIES IN THE GRANT DOCUMENT WAS NEVER ADJUSTED TO THE FUNDING REALITIES LIMITING THE PROJECT TO THE INITIAL $1,000,000 AUTHORIZATION. SINCE LATE 1973, PROJECT MANAGEMENT BY AID HAS GENERALLY BEEN SPOTTY AND INADEQUATE, AND AT TIMES, CLEARLY MISLEADING TO THE GRANTEE. THE QUALITY OF PASITAM'S (PROGRAM OF ADVANCED STUDY IN INSTITUTION DEVELOPMENT AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE METHODOLOGY) PROUDCTS IS VARIABLE, FROM EXCELLENT TO FAIR, WITH THE  AVERAGE OF SUFFICIENT UTILITY TO JUSTIFY THE EFFORTS AND EXPENDITURES INVOLVED. PASITAM IS NOT MAKING FULL USE OF MUCIA (MIDWESTERN UNIVERSITIES CONSORTIUM FOR INTERNATIONAL ACTIVITIES) RESOURCES; NOR IS MUCIA ADEQUATELY USING PASITAM AS A POTENTIAL CONSORTIUM CLEARINGHOUSE IN DEVELOPMENT OPERATIONS. PASITAM HAS ACHIEVED SUFFICIENT RECOGNITION AND VISIBILITY TO ATTRACT THE INTEREST OF POTENTIAL CLIENTELE TO ITSELF, MUCIA AND ITS MEMBER INSTITUTIONS; IT OPERATES INCREASINGLY AS AN ORGANIZATION IN ITS OWN RIGHT AND LESS AS AN INSTRUMENT OF MUCIA. THE EVALUATORS MADE 16 RECOMMENDATIONS TO AID, MUCIA AND PASITAM INCLUDING THAT AID PROVIDE NO ADDITIONAL FUNDING TO THE GRANT AS NOW CONCEIVED BUT THAT IT EXTEND THE TIME FRAME FOR FULL UTILIZATION OF FUNDING BY ONE YEAR.

Title: COMPREHENSIVE (FOURTH YEAR) REVIEW OF SEC. 211(D) GRANT AID/CSD 2958, MAY 28, 1971

Abstract: THE AGRICULTURAL SECTOR IMPLEMENTATION PROJECT (ASIP) HAS ESSENTIAL WORTH IN BOTH ITS CONCEPTION AND IMPLEMENTATION. GIVEN THE PURPOSE OF THE PROJECT AND ITS TRAINING OBJECT, THE CONTRACTOR HAS PRODUCED THE MATERIALS IT CONTRACTED TO PRODUCE AND THESE, WITH SOME MODIFICATION AND FINALIZING, CAN BE ADAPTED AND FIELD TESTED WITH APPROPRIATE TRAINING INSTITUTIONS IN ONE OR MORE SELECTED LDC'S. THE OUTPUTS PRODUCED THUS FAR SHOULD HAVE BEEN COMPLETED IN A SHORTER TIME FRAME AND FOR LESS COST. PERFORMANCE HAS NOT BEEN FULLY RESPONSIVE TO WHAT WAS ORIGINALLY SOUGHT. THERE IS EVIDENCE THAT DIFFERENCES IN INTERPRETATION, LACK OF UNDERSTANDING AND POOR COMMUNICATIONS BETWEEN THE AID REPRESENTATIVE AND THE DIRECTOR OR THE ASIP STAFF RESULTED IN DELAYS AND A PRODUCT OUTPUT WHICH,IN THE OPINION OF THE EVALUATORS,NEEDS RE-WORKING. THE EVALUATORS BELIEVE THAT AID DID NOT GIVE ADEQUATE AND SUFFICIENT ATTENTION TO THE PROJECT DURING ITS IMPLEMENTATION. PROFESSIONAL STAFFING OF THIS PROJECT WAS WEAK GIVEN THE STATED OBJECTIVES. ONE OF THE PRINCIPAL OUTPUTS OF THE PROJECT, THE SOURCE BOOK OF TRAINING MATERIALS, HAS ELICITED CONSIDERABLE NEGATIVE CRITICISM BY A CROSS-SECTION OF AID OFFICERS, SEMINAR PARTICIPANTS, AND OTHERS INTERESTED IN DEVELOPMENT WORK. GENERALLY, THE CRITICISMS HAVE RELATED TO DEFINING THE TARGET AUDIENCE, MATERIALS ORGANIZATION, SUBSTANCE AND UTILIZATION, ABSENCE OF AID EXPERIENCE, AND HEAVY EMPHASIS ON PLANNING OVER MANAGEMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION. VERY LITTLE WAS DONE ABOUT MEETING THE CRITICISMS BY EITHER THE CONTRACTOR OR THE AID BACKSTOP. THE EVALUATORS MADE SIX RECOMMENDATIONS INCLUDING THAT AID CONTINUE TO PURSUE THE PROJECT GOAL AND PROVIDE ADEQUATE FUNDING TO BRING THE TRAINING SYSTEM AND MATERIALS TO AT LEAST TWO CAREFULLY SELECTED LDC'S.

Title: REVIEW OF GOVERNMENTAL AFFAIRS INSTITUTE - AGRICULTURAL SECTOR IMPLEMENTATION PROJECT

Abstract: THE SCOPE OF THIS PROJECT IS DIVERSE; THE TECHNICAL OUTPUT IS GREAT; AND THE NUMBER OF COUNTRIES WHERE GE-TEMPO HAS BEENINVOLVED IS CONSIDERABLE. THE EVALUATION DISCUSSED: (1)COUNTRY STUDIES; (2)CONSULTANT SERVICES; (3)TRAINING; AND (4)STAFF STUDIES. UNDER THE FIRST CONTRACT AN ECONOMIC-DEMOGRAPHIC MODEL CALLED TEMPO I WAS CONSTRUCTED TO EXPLORE THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN DEMOGRAPHIC CHANGE AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT. TEMPO I IS A SIMPLE, YET ADEQUATE, MODEL TO DEMONSTRATE THE IMPORTANCE OF DEMOGRAPHIC VARIABLES IN DEVELOPMENT PLANNING. THE LIMITS OF TEMPO I, BECAUSE IT IS HIGHLY AGGREGATED AND SOMEWHAT OVERSIMPLIFIED, ARE ALSO ITS STRENGTHS SINCE BASIC DEMOGRAPHIC-ECONOMIC INTERACTIONS CAN BE DEMONSTRATED WITHOUT BEING OBSCURED BY UNDUE MODEL COMPLEXITY. SEVERAL OF THE SHORTCOMINGS OF TEMPO I WERE OVERCOME IN TEMPO II. THE TWO MAJOR USES OF TEMPO I ARE TO SHOW THAT FERTILITY DECLINE INCREASES GROWTH IN PER CAPITA INCOME OF LDC'S UNDER A WIDE VARIETY OF CIRCUMSTANCES AND TO PROVIDE INSTRUCTION OF ECONOMIC-DEMOGRAPHIC INTERACTION. THE PURPOSE OF TEMPO II IS TO MAKE AVAILABLE A FLEXIBLE TOOL OF ANALYSIS WHICH MID-LEVEL GOVERNMENT PLANNERS IN DEVELOPING COUNTRIES CAN USE TO STUDY THE LONG-RANGE, COUNTRY-SPECIFIC IMPLICATIONS OF ECONOMIC-DEMOGRAPHIC INTERACTIONS. WHILE MARKING AN ADVANCE IN SOPHISTICATION OVER TEMPO I, THERE ARE ALSO FACTORS OPERATING WHICH TEND TO REDUCE THE USEFULNESS OF TEMPO II. THE ISSUANCE OF THE DEMOS MANUAL REPRESENTS PERHAPS THE MOST IMPORTANT CONTRIBUTION THAT HAS BEEN MADE TO THE POPULATION FIELD BY GE-TEMPO, ALTHOUGH IT IS STILL TOO EARLY TO ASSESS THE IMPACT OF THE MANUAL. THE EVALUATOR MADE 8 SPECIFIC RECOMMENDATIONS INCLUDING THAT THE PROGRAM SHOULD: (1)CONCENTRATE ON COUNTRY STUDIES: (2)ACCELERATE MOVEMENT OF TEMPO RESEARCH TO MICRO AND SECTORAL STUDIES; AND (3)INVOLVE LOCAL LDC PERSONNEL TO A GREATER DEGREE IN PROJECT ACTIONS AND DIRECT STUDIES EXPLICITLY TO NEEDS OF LDC OFFICIALS.

Abstract: THE INTERNATIONAL FERTILITY RESEARCH PROGRAM (IFRP) IS CURRENTLY SUPERVISING INVESTIGATIONS AT 91 CENTERS LOCATED IN 21 COUNTRIES. IT APPEARS TO BE PERFORMING AN EXCELLENT JOB IN TESTING PROMISING DEVELOPMENTS AND IN ASSISTING THE INTRODUCTION OF INNOVATIONS, TWO OF ITS THREE OBJECTIVES. IT IS DIFFICULT TO ASSESS THE IMPACT OF CURRENT IFRP TECHNIQUES IN DISSEMINATION OF INFORMATION, ITS THIRD OBJECTIVE. THE DISTRIBUTION OF PREPRINTS AND SELF-PRINTED PAPERS APPARENTLY REACHES A LIMITED BUT HIGHLY SELECTED AUDIENCE. GREATER EFFORTS SHOULD BE MADE TO CONTINUE THE WORK OF PRESENTING CONCURRENT WORKSHOPS, OR HAVING CONTRIBUTOR PRESENTATIONS AT REGIONAL MEETINGS WHERE THEIR WORK CAN BE DISCUSSED AND DISSEMINATED IN THE AREA. CONTRIBUTORS WORKSHOPS AND MEETINGS APPEAR TO BE POPULAR AND VALUABLE TO THE COOPERATING CENTERS AND SHOULD BE ENCOURAGED. IT WOULD BE DESIRABLE IF MORE OF THESE COULD BE APPENDED TO REGIONAL AND INTERNATIONAL MEETINGS. A NUMBER OF PROBLEMS APPEARED DURING THE SITE VISITS, SOME RELATED TO THE SEPARATION OF IFRP FROM THE UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AND OTHERS TO INDIFFERENT PROCESSING OF COMMUNICATIONS FROM CONTRIBUTORS. THE EVALUATORS DISCUSSED THEIR SPECIFIC FINDINGS AND OBSERVATIONS ABOUT THE PROGRAM AT NORTH CAROLINA, LONDON, LJUBLJANA, CAIRO, ASSUIT, BANGKOK, SINGAPORE, JAKARTA, DEN PENSAR, SEOUL, AND THE CONFERENCE AT PALM SPRINGS. THEY ALSO MADE GENERAL OBSERVATIONS AND RECOMMENDATIONS ABOUT CLINICAL ASPECTS OF THE PROGRAM AND ABOUT ADMINISTRATIVE MATTERS SUCH AS RECORD KEEPING, FISCAL MANAGEMENT, AND RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN CONTRIBUTORS AND IFRP.

Abstract: IN GENERAL, THE EVALUATION TEAM CONCLUDED THAT THE PATHFINDER FUND HAS BEEN MEETING ITS OBJECTIVES AS STATED IN ITS GRANT FROM AID. THE EVALUATION FOCUSSED ON CERTAIN GENERIC AREAS OF PERFORMANCE, NAMELY: BASIC ASSUMPTIONS; DIRECTIONS AND OBJECTIVES; RELATIONSHIPS; STAFFING PATTERNS; COMMUNICATIONS; AND PROJECT SELECTION, SUPPORT, EVALUATION AND FEEDBACK. THE EVALUATORS AGREED THAT AT THIS POINT PATHFINDER HAS A CHALLENGE TO RE-THINK AND RE-DEFINE ITS UNDERLYING ASSUMPTIONS, GOALS, AND OBJECTIVES IN ORDER BETTER TO EXPRESS ITS BASIC ROLE AS AN ORGANIZATION DEDICATED TO LENDING THE WAY, TO ENCOURAGING AND SUPPORTING INNOVATIVE APPROACHES TO SOLVING MANKIND'S POPULATION CRISIS. THE TEAM FOUND LITTLE INDICATION THAT PATHFINDER PRESENTLY HAS A CLEAR UNDERSTANDING OF THE ASSUMPTIONS UPON WHICH ITS PROGRAM ACTIVITIES AND STATED OBJECTIVES ARE BASED. THE RANGE AND VARIETY OF PROJECTS SUGGEST THAT PATHFINDER LACKS THE POLICY DIRECTION NECESSARY TO BE CONSISTENTLY SELECTIVE IN PROJECT CONSIDERATION, DEVELOPMENT AND ACCEPTANCE FOR FUNDING. THIS LACK OF WELL-DEFINED CRITERIA FOR PROJECT SELECTION PRESENTS AN OBSTACLE WHICH NOW APPEARS TO LIMIT PATHFINDER OPERATIONS. IT WAS THE CONSENSUS OF THE TEAM THAT PATHFINDER HAS COME UNDER UNDUE EXTERNAL INFLUENCE BECAUSE OF THE ABSENCE OF A WELL-DEFINED BASIS FOR ITS OPERATIONS. THE RE-EXAMINATION AND EXPLICIT RE-STATEMENT OF ITS BASIC ASSUMPTIONS AND OBJECTIVES WAS THE CENTRAL RECOMMENDDATION OF THE EVALUATION. THE EVALUATORS MADE 21 RECOMMENDATIONS ABOUT THE FIVE GENERIC AREAS OF PERFORMANCE INCLUDING THAT: (1)PATHFINDER SHOULD DEVELOP A SYSTEM OF GUIDELINES WHEREBY PROJECT APPLICATIONS CAN BE EVALUATED ACCORDING TO CLEARLY DEFINED PRIORITIES; AND (2)PATHFINDER SHOULD CONSIDER DEVELOPMENT OF AN EVALUATION SYSTEM AMONG ITS HIGHEST PRIORITIES FOR THE IMMEDIATE FUTURE.

Abstract: THE PLATO (PROGRAMMED LOGIC FOR AUTOMATED TEACHING OPERATIONS) SYSTEM IN POPULATION DYNAMICS HAS MANY GOOD FEATURES TO RECOMMEND IT. THE COMPUTER TECHNOLOGY IS SOPHISTICATED AND PROVIDES A RAPID FEEDBACK OF INFORMATION. THE MODE OF PRESENTATION ATTRACTS CONSIDERABLE INTEREST. THE ABILITY TO FOCUS ON THE CONSEQUENCES OF POPULATION GROWTH FOR AN INDIVIDUAL COUNTRY ADDS GREATLY TO PRESENTATIONS OF POPULATION DYNAMICS. THE USER CAN INTERACT WITH PLATO AND, IF TEACHING MATERIALS ARE WELL PREPARED, PLATO CAN BE AN EXCELLENT TEACHING DEVICE. AT PRESENT, THE PRIMARY USE OF PLATO HAS BEEN FOR DEMONSTRATIONS OF POPULATION AWARENESS. THE RESPONSE OF MOST VIEWERS HAS BEEN FAVORABLE. BUT IT IS DIFFICULT TO ASSESS JUST HOW MUCH, OR HOW WELL, BASIC RELATIONSHIPS AND CONCEPTS HAVE BEEN UNDERSTOOD. TIME LIMITATIONS PRECLUDE PARTICIPANTS RECEIVING MORE THAN A LIMITED AWARENESS OF POPULATION IMPLICATIONS, BUT PLATO DOES WELL FOR THE TIME ALLOWED. THE FULL CAPABILITIES OF PLATO ARE NOT BEING REALIZED, LARGELY DUE TO THE CONSTRUCTION OF OVERLY SIMPLISTIC MODELS. PLATO CAN BE USED FOR POPULATION AWARENESS DEMONSTRATIONS, BUT NOT WITHOUT SUBSTANTIAL TECHNICAL IMPROVEMENT IN THE CONSTRUCTION OF THE MODELS, THE NATURE OF THE ASSUMPTIONS MADE, AND THE METHODOLOGIES EMPLOYED, THE MODELS ARE INADEQUATELY LINKED TOGETHER AND DO NOT SUFFICIENTLY REFLECT THE IMPACT OF POPULATION SIZE, GROWTH, AND COMPOSITION ON ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL FACTORS. THE OVERALL RECOMMENDATIONS ARE: (1) LIMIT THE USE OF PLATO TO POPULATION AWARENESS; (2) RECONSTRUCT MODELS FOR POPULATION PROJECTIONS, ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT, AND EDUCATION; (3) DO NOT DEVELOP OR USE OTHER MODELS AT THIS TIME; AND (4) DO NOT INITIATE INSTALLATION OF THE MINI-COMPUTER. THE EVALUATORS CRITIQUED FIVE MODELS; MADE 9 SPECIFIC RECOMMENDATIONS ABOUT THE POPULATION PROJECTION MODEL AND THE ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT MODEL; AND DISCUSSED USES AND LIMITATIONS OF THE PLATO PROGRAM.

Title: EVALUATION REPORT; COMPUTER ASSISTED INSTRUCTION IN POPULATION DYNAMICS FOR NATIONAL PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT PLANNING AND EVALUATION

Abstract: THE PROGRAM CONCERNED ITSELF WITH SIX AREAS: CREDIT, DEVELOPMENT OF HUMAN RESOURCES, MARKETING, DISTRIBUTION OF MATERIALS, RURAL ADMINISTRATION, AND ROAD CONSTRUCTION. A NUMBER OF INSTITUTIONS WERE CHARGED WITH ADMINISTRATION OF VARIOUS SEGMENTS OF THE PROGRAM. THE PROGRAM WAS EVALUATED FROM THE PERSPECTIVES OF ECONOMIC IMPACT, TECHNICAL OPERATIONS, AND FINANCIAL ADMINISTRATION. ON THE WHOLE, PERFORMANCE WAS MODERATELY SUCCESSFUL, BUT THE ADMINISTRATION OF THE PROGRAM THROUGHOUT 1975 WAS RATHER UNEVEN, WITH MOST DIFFICULTIES ARISING FROM INADEQUATE COORDINATION BETWEEN THE PARTICIPATING AGENCIES. THERE WAS AN EIGHT-WEEK DELAY IN THE START-UP OF THE CREDIT PROGRAM DUE TO POOR PLANNING ON THE PART OF THE AGRICULTURAL BANK AS WELL AS DEFICIENCIES IN THE SELECTION AND TRAINING OF TECHNICAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE PERSONNEL. POOR COMMUNICATION BETWEEN BANKS AND THE SECRETARIAT OF AGRICULTURE RESULTED IN INSUFFICIENT AND LATE DISBURSEMENTS. THE DISTRIBUTION PROGRAM FARED BETTER; IT REACHED A TOTAL OF 9,000 FARMERS. ALTHOUGH THE CREATION OF NEW DISTRIBUTION CENTERS POSED THE PROBLEM OF HIRING QUALIFIED PERSONNEL, CONTROL OVER OPERATIONS WAS MAINTAINED. IT IS HOPED THAT WITH THE INCREASING ACTIVITY, THERE WILL BE A SIGNIFICANT REDUCTION IN COSTS. BOTH THE MARKETING AND PROPERTY ADMINISTRATION PROGRAM ENCOUNTERED TYPICAL PROBLEMS: LACK OR DEFICIENCY OF PERSONNEL, PAUCITY OF EQUIPMENT AND MATERIALS, AND LITTLE OR NO MEANS OF TRANSPORTATION, ALL OF WHICH CAN BE ATTRIBUTED TO LACK OF FUNDS. NEVERTHELESS, THE DEDICATION OF RESPONSIBLE PERSONNEL HAS OVERCOME THESE INITIAL DIFFICULTIES TO A LARGE EXTENT. IN THE AREA OF HUMAN RESOURCES, THE VOCATIONAL EDUCATION EFFORT REACHED 2,000 SMALL FARMERS IN SPITE OF POOR COORDINATION BETWEEN RESPONSIBLE INSTITUTIONS. IT IS RECOMMENDED THAT A PERMANENT EVALUATING COMMITTEE BE ESTABLISHED TO EVALUATE ALL ACTIVITIES AND PROJECTS ON AN ONGOING BASIS.

Abstract: THIS PROJECT IS BASICALLY SUCCESSFUL AND IT WAS A GOOD MAJOR INVESTMENT. WITH FEW MINOR EXCEPTIONS, THE FORMAL TRAINING OBJECTIVES HAVE BEEN MET WITH POSITIVE NET RESULTS. THE PROGRAM PROVIDED THE FUNDAMENTAL EDUCATIONAL TRAINING WHICH NOW ENABLES THE STAFF TO UNDERTAKE MEANINGFUL RESEARCH, AND IS, ON BALANCE, THE MOST SUCCESSFUL AND HIGHLY SIGNIFICANT ELEMENT OF THE PROGRAM. THE EVALUATORS BELIEVE THAT THE ON-THE-JOB RESEARCH AND PLANNING GUIDANCE BY MINNESOTA STAFF RESIDENT IN TUNISIA IS STILL A NEED AND THAT FOREIGN EXPERTS PLAY A USEFUL ROLE. THEY BELIEVE THE OBJECTIVE CAN BE ACHIEVED IN A MORE EFFICIENT MANNER. INITIALLY, NO TUNISIAN COUNTERPARTS WERE AVAILABLE TO WORK WITH THE US STAFF. FOREIGN EXPERTS WORKED DIRECTLY ON AGREED-UPON PROBLEMS OF A MAJOR SUBSECTOR OF TUNISIAN AGRICULTURE. GENERALLY, THE TEAM MEMBERS WERE REGARDED AS EFFECTIVE RESEARCHERS, BUT THE QUANTITY AND QUALITY OF THEIR RESEARCH WAS CONSTRAINED BY LACK OF DATA AND A RESEARCH BASE ON WHICH TO BUILD. UTILIZATION OF THE RESEARCH, WHILE SIGNIFICANT IN SOME INSTANCES, ALSO SUFFERED. THE MOST IMPORTANT ELEMENT OF THIS COMPONENT IS THE CAPACITY FOR RESEARCH THAT HAS BEEN CREATED IN THE MINISTRY OF AGRICULTURE, PRIMARILY IN THE BUREAU OF PLAN. THE EFFORTS OF THE PROJECT IN PLANNING HAVE ONLY RECENTLY BEGUN TO PAY OFF AS PARTICIPANTS RETURN AND OCCUPY KEY ROLES ON PLANNING COMMITTEES. THE EVALUATORS MADE RECOMMENDATIONS ABOUT EXPANDING THE PROGRAM, MAKING MINOR CHANGES IN THE CURRENT PROGRAM, AND APPROVING THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PRESENTLY BEING PROPOSED.

Abstract: Evaluates project performance from 1971 to 1975 in Puerto Rico (PR). Loan was made to help University of Puerto Rico (UPR) identify soil types & concentrate on soil conservation.  This was an on-site team evaluation conducted through group sessions with faculty & students. UPR developed a soils research program & improved its physical facilities, educational materials & staff.  Principal areas improved were production of starch root crops & edible legumes & soil analysis of tropical soils.  Communication with other institutions was increased. Ongoing research at UPR & the University of Hawaii may establish methodology for tropical soil classification data. Utilization of grant has been disappointing, primarily because UPR did not conduct any soil conservation studies.  Many team members felt UPR was caught in a bind in trying to build its graduate soils program -- and at the same time develop & expand its knowledge base applicable to Less Developed Countries (LDC's).  Other disappointments were UPR's failure to:  coordinate its research with other institutions; optimally use funds (expenditures were approved by Department head & not Grant Project Director); recruit either staff or LDC students; effectively coordinate personnel; fully report soil composition useful to LDC problems; & utilize the capacities of UPR in Latin America. Since UPR is not located in an area conducive to soil conservation research & its present strengths are in other areas, it was recommended that emphasis shift from conservation & protection to classification & geography of soils in the tropics, land planning, land use evaluation & technology transfer.  Team feels financial assistance should be continued only if UPR: recruits new staff for research, not teaching; has expenditures approved only by the Grant Project Director; increases its capacity to classify tropical soils; begins research in soil taxonomy; develops a soil data base; assembles "package" programs of information on numerous crops for LDC's; produces state-of-the-art reviews; & conducts more field research using research stations.

Abstract: Evaluates performance of the "Rapid Feedback for Family Planning Improvement" (RFFPI) project for the period 6/25/69 - 6/30/75.  The project consists of a contract with the Community and Family Study Center (CFSC) at the University of Chicago. The purpose is to improve the evaluation of family planning programs in LDC's. Evaluation is based on meetings with CFSC personnel at the University of Chicago and a review of project documentation. CFSC helped create an awareness of the field of family planning evaluation in LDC's. 7,000 copies of RFFPI manual #1 have been distributed which define the field of family planning evaluation. CFSC also developed a series of 12 manuals which include "cookbook" instructions on various evaluation methodologies. CFSC developed a series of computer programs for these methodologies and distributed them to LDC's free of charge.  The MINI-TAB programs are written in Fortran for use on small computers (32K memory). They include pregnancy history analysis, cross-tabulations, client record tabulations, and multiple regression programs.  CFSC helped install MINI-TAB programs in Pakistan, Bangladesh, Thailand, Philippines, Indonesia, Malaysia, South Korea, Columbia, and other countries. Computer data processing is now readily available to any LDC on a cheap, easy, and efficient basis. To create indigenous capabilities in family planning evaluation, CFSC has conducted a 3-prong training program:  short-term workshops in host countries, summer workshops at Chicago, and MA and PhD training at Chicago. All have been successful. Technical assistance provided by the CFSC has also had visible impact on several LDC's.  Report cites as an example, the model evaluation program established in Indonesia. Report recommends extending the project 3 more years.  Future activities should emphasize the measurement of the demographic impact of AID-funded family planning programs.

Abstract: Evaluates sector loan to create a regionalized integrated health delivery system in Colombia including:  a) provision of infrastructure to support the system; b) development of intra and inter-sectorial mechanisms of coordination; and c) efforts to lower system costs by cost effectiveness analysis from 1/1/74 to 12/31/74.  Evaluation format is based on the logframe, containing statements of progress at each level (goal, purpose and outputs).  Information presented is the result of a conscious use of management by exception to locate weakness and difficulties in the health program. Evaluators note marked improvements in the health sector, especially in the development of information systems and in improving the planning and implementation of health facility construction.  Additional attention was given to human resources development and the regionalization scheme by the planning office in the Ministry of Health. These activities are expected to result in greater integration of planning at the regional level and human resources and equipment more in line with updated policies and priorities. Several problems are also noted.  A change in govt in August, 1974 caused a 6-9 month slow down in the health sector.  Vacancies created by people leaving their positions due to the change were not quickly filled.  In addition, the immediate emphasis of the new administration on fiscal reform and reduction of investment to control inflation did little to enhance the possibility of short-term progress in the health sector. The requirement of sector activity progress reports is seen as having a salutary effect on the GOC ability to deal with the health sector in a more systematic fashion. Although not uniformly complied with, the conditions of the loan provided a useful framework within which to maintain support for essential elements of GOC health policy.

Abstract: Evaluates USAID assistance to Morocco from 1971 to 1974 to develop indigenous expertise in the fields of agronomy and veterinary science. The major problems in the project developed from AID's misunderstanding of the role, objectives and official context of the Hassan II Institute of Agronomy and Veterinary Science (the proj beneficiary). Because of this misunderstanding, the University of Minnesota contract team was sometimes frustrated and out of synchrony with the ojectives of H II Inst.  While American universities place great emphasis on research, under the European system followed by H II Inst, field and laboratory research are considered technical pursuits inappropriate to intellectuals and scholars. As a result, some US team members had no students to supervise for the first two years.  A research program to develop improved and disease-resistant barley varieties was effectively implemented. Research and study efforts were also directed toward crop viruses and soil conditions.  One team member is producing a textbook on Moroccan soils, their classifications and productive capabilities. Since 1974, the average number of sixth-year students per faculty member rose from 1.0 to 1.6.  Evaluators note that the above figure is misleading since US faculty members often give advice to students not officially assigned to them. The major flaws in the project were the inability of AID-supported faculty to attract motivated researchers to replace them and the failure of Hassan II administrators to place a high priority on the Moroccanization of its research and teaching staff. The evaluators recommend that USAID assign project technicians only to those disciplines for which counterparts are provided and a US faculty replacement is likely within one or two years.

Abstract: Analyzes the organizational structure and the number and type of personnel employed at the Philadelphia headquarters of Opportunities Industrialization Centers International (OICI) as of 6/12/75.  AID has contracted OICI to assist in establishing Opportunities Industrialization Centers (non-formal vocational training centers) in Ghana, Nigeria, Ethiopia, and Kenya.  The evaluation is based on interviews with OICI staff and AID/W officials. OICI and AID are not using common indicators to measure program performance.  OICI measures effectiveness in terms of numbers of the target group trained, the skills in which they are trained, job placements, and job retention.  AID measures OICI's performance in terms of viability (i.e., achievement of 100% local funding of the training centers) within the 3-year target for self-sufficiency.  In order to obtain agreement on performance indicators, use of the logframe is suggested. AID and OICI should also seek agreement on a realistically longer period for attainment of full local funding.  For new OICI programs which are under preparation, both parties should re-examine the practicability of the underlying concept of complete viability in OICI's target countries. As OICI seeks to relate to the needs of new target countries, it may depart radically from service and manufacturing industry skill training in which it has expertise.  Should AID be in accord with OICI entry into rural development and agricultural production, OICI will have to add agricultural/rural development expertise to its headquarters staff. OICI has 17 positions:  11 professional and 6 clerical/secretarial. This headquarters staff backstops 16 US technicians and 45 local nationals in 4 African nations.  While the central office staff may well be irreducible, the type and quality of staff can be modified to assure better levels of accomplishment.  OICI should tighten qualifications for some of its professional positions to strengthen its planning, analytical, and evaluative capabilities.  In addition, OICI is urged to utilize more fully the seasoned staff of OIC/America and other entities established by Rev. Sullivan.

Abstract: Evaluates the evaluation methodology used to determine the effectiveness of the radiophonic schools component of the Nicaraguan Rural Community Health Service Project (PRACS).  PRACS is intended to provide rural health extension services, paramedical & hlth educator training, and public hlth educ.  The radiophonic schools component utilizes radio instruction & classroom discussion to inform community members of beneficial hlth & hygiene practices while providing experiential trng to hlth educators in radiophonic teaching methods. The eval was conducted by interviewing key schl personnel and studying the evaluative information which was generated by 2 hlth & hygiene trng courses for pregnant women. Participants were tested orally before & after the courses.  Tests were done one by one as many of the participants were illiterate.  The tests were apparently not conducted nor recorded properly as there was no knowledge change with some of the students. Also, there was some lack of correlation between info tested & info transmitted and evidence of testing info which had no relevance to actions within the control of the rural mother (eg, clinical procedures).  In addition to rectifying the above test deficiencies, it is recommended that the wording of the test questions be improved and that more efficient test procedures be developed. There was no scientific eval of change in hlth habits & practices of the women participants.  Progress charts were developed which measured the positive actions of graduates of the 1st course during the 3 mos after they gave birth.  This chart cannot be considered as a true eval tool as the target group surveyed had access to other info inputs and that the charts do not record reasons for non-action or reversal of actions.  It is recommended that info available in the community hlth diagnosis be examined and the hlth promoters & the women, themselves, be interviewed to compare the actions of those trnd by existing programs with those who also attended the radiophonic schls. There was also no credible eval of the incentives used to maintain schl attendance.

Abstract: EVALUATES THE CAPABILITY OF THE PROJECT LOAN RECIPIENT, THE LATIN AMERICAN AGRIBUSINESS DEVELOPMENT CORP  (LAAD), TO EXPAND ITS OPERATIONS INTO THE CARIBBEAN AREA  (INCLUDING COLOMBIA). LAAD PROVIDES LOW-INTEREST LOANS TO LAT AMER AGRIBUSINESSES AND ALSO MAKES EQUITY INVESTMENTS IN THESE ENTERPRISES. PURPOSE OF PROJ IS TO INCREASE LAAD'S AVAILABLE LOAN CAPITAL AND THEREBY INCREASE THE NO OF AGRIBUSINESSES WHICH COULD OBTAIN CREDIT. INFORMATION FOR THIS EVAL WAS DEVELOPED THROUGH AUTHOR'S BRIEF VISIT TO LAAD OFFICES IN MIAMI & GUATEMALA CITY AND DISCUSSIONS WITH THE MANAGERS OF THOSE OFFICES. IT APPEARED THAT EXISTING LAAD LOANS WERE SENSIBLE AND THE ENTERPRISES WHICH HAD RECEIVED CREDIT WERE IN ON DANGER OF FAILING. ALTHOUGH LAAD INTENDS TO MAKE LOANS TO PROMOTE ENTERPRISES WHICH WOULD PEOVIDE "NEW" GOODS TO THE MARKETPLACE,PRESENTLY,MOST OF THE LOANS ARE BEING PROVIDED TO MORE PROVEN AGRIBUSINESSES. THE STAFF OF THE VARIOUS LAAD OFFICES SEEMS HIGHLY QUALIFIELD AND IS ADEQUATE FOR PRESENT TASTS. IT WILL REQUIRE STRENGTHENING IF THIS 2ND AID LOAN IS TO BE PROPERLY ADMIITERED,DISBURSED & MONITORED. LAAD HAS PRESENTED ADDIT STAFFING PLANS WHICH ARE JUDGED AS APPROPRIATE. AT PRESENT,LAAD/MIAMI & LAAD/CA HAVE BEEN MUTUALLY SUPPORTIVE WHEN NECESSARY BUT BOTH HAVE BEEN ABLE TO FUNCTION INDEPENDENT OF ASSISTANCE. IT IS,THEREFORE,CONCLUDED THAT ESTABLISHMENT OF AN ADDIT OFFICE WOULD NOT DETRACT FROM THE OPERATIONS OF THE EXISTING OFFICE. THE EXPERIENCE GAINED BY LAAD/CA IN ITS CENT AMER OPERATNS COULD BE BENEFICIALLY APPLIED TO THE INITIAL OPERATNS OF A CARIBBEAN OFFICE. THE MKTG CONTACTS ALREADY ESTABLISHED BY LAAD-MARKETING COULD BE UTILIZED BY LAAD/CARIBE-SUPPORTED AGRIBUSINESSES AND SUCH UTILIZATN WOULD RECIPROCALLY STRENGTHEN LAAD-MKTG. ITS ACCEPTANCE IN THE AREA WOULD SEEM ASSURED AS NO SIMILAR LENDING INSTIT CURRENTLY EXISTS. IT IS RECOMMENDED,THEREFORE,THAT A 2ND LOAN TO LAAD IS FEASIBLE ALTHOUGH AID SHOULD RECONSIDER ITS PLAN FOR ADMINISTERING THE LOAN IN WASHINGTON. IN ORDER TO CENTRALIZE ADMIN OF THE LOAN,SUCH RESPONSIBILITIES COULD BE GIVEN TO A CARIBBEAN AID MISSION OR TO A CONTRACTOR EXPERT IN AGRIBUSINESS DEVELOPMENT.

Abstract: EVALUATES THE RURAL ENTERPRISES DEVELOPMENT LOAN TO PERU AFTER 6 MONTHS OF OPERATION (12/16/75). THE RURAL ENTERPRISE DEVELOPMENT FUND, ADMINISTERED BY THE BANCO INDUSTRIAL DEL PERU, IS INTENDED TO PROVIDE CREDIT AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO RURAL ENTERPRISES WHICH DO NOT HAVE NORMAL ACCESS TO CREDIT ON REASONABLE TERMS AND CONDITIONS. THE 3-WEEK EVALUATION INCLUDED INTERVIEWS WITH BANK OFFICIALS IN LIMA AND 2 OF THE 4 REGIONAL BRANCH OFFICES OF THE BANK. THE BANK HAS EMPLOYED 3 "PROMOTORES" TO HEAD THE FUND'S OPERATIONS IN THE REGIONAL BRANCHES. DURING THE FIRST 6 MONTHS OF THE FUND'S EXISTENCE, ONLY 7 SUB-LOANS REPRESENTING LESS THAN 1% OF THE ENTIRE FUND HAVE BEEN APPROVED. THE AUTHORS RECOMMEND THAT THE BANK GENERAL MANAGER COMMUNICATE TO BRANCH PERSONNEL, NOT ONLY THE PRIORITY OF "MOVING THE FUND" AT THE BRANCH LEVEL, BUT ALSO THE SPIRIT OF THE PROGRAM AS WELL. BRANCH PERSONNEL DO NOT HAVE A CLEAR UNDERSTANDING OF THE FUND'S PURPOSE. SUB-LOANS ARE BEING MADE TO PARTIES ELIGIBLE FOR COMMERCIAL BANK FINANCING. ONE BRANCH MANAGER STATED THAT HIS UNDERSTANDING OF THE FUND WAS MERELY THAT IT "OFFERED LOWER INTEREST RATES", AND ADDED THAT THE BRANCH OFFICE WOULD CONTINUE TO REQUIRE 100% GUARANTEES FOR ALL SUB-LOANS.
